336311	25430	277112	336311	336311	2019-10-17 18:10:36	Add ability to create new repo groups from CLI	Users now have the ability to create new repo groups in the database specified in their config file. \r\n\r\nThis can be done by using the command `augur db add_repo_groups /path/to/repo_groups.csv` where `repo_groups.csv` is a valid `.csv` file with the following format:\r\n```\r\n<repo_group_id>,<repo_group_name>\r\n...\r\n```\r\n\r\nWhere `<repo_group_id>` is the desired ID of the new repo group, and `<repo_group_name>` is the desired name of the new repo group. \r\n\r\nEach pair of values should be on its own line (indicated by the `...`), without quotes, and there should be no column headers. An example of a valid file follows:\r\n```\r\n20,Apache Camel\r\n21,Apache DeltaSpike\r\n22,Apache Qpid\r\n23,Apache Tomcat\r\n```\r\n\r\nThere is also a new helper command `augur db get_repo_groups` which will retrieve information about the repo groups that already exist in the database.	277110	0	2019-10-17 19:31:48	2019-10-17 19:31:48	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/423	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/423/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/423/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/423/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/pull/423	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MzI5MzkzODIw	508638424	31522931	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:06:43	423

have it)\r\n4) Make sure your path has the Python and Python scripts directory\r\n5) Add an environment variable for HOME = %USERPROFILE%\r\n6) Install node/npm\r\n7) Install @vue\\cli\r\n8) Enable bash (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36352627/how-to-enable-bash-in-windows-10-developer-preview)\r\n\t\r\n\r\nThe Python installation instructions can be found here:\r\nhttps://timmyreilly.azurewebsites.net/python-pip-virtualenv-installation-on-windows/\r\n\r\nInstructions on how to use mkvirtualenv can be found here:\r\nhttps://virtualenvwrapper.readthedocs.io/en/latest/command_ref.html\r\n\r\nBack to the instructions\r\n0: Clone the repository using the Git GUI and check out the correct branch/version\r\n\r\nFor Visual Studio\r\n=================\r\n0: Start up a developer command prompt\r\n\r\n1: Create a virtual environment: mkvirtualenv Augur_env\r\n\t(This creates it at C:\\Users\\<username>\\.virtualenvs\\augur_env\r\n\tCreate a directory where you want to link the virtual directory to and cd into it e.g.\r\n\tC:\\Users\\<username>\\Augur_env\r\n\tActivate the virtual environment:\r\n\tsetprojectdir .\r\n\t\r\nNote: if you already have the environment then the creation won't work and you need to type workon Augur_env\r\n\t\r\n2: Start the installation process\r\n\ta) cd into the GIT directory (e.g. C:\\GIT\\CHAOSS)\r\n\tb) type nmake install\r\n\tc) go grab a coffee whilst the installation happens\r\n\td) don't choose the webpage option for 336348	25430	277110	\N	\N	2019-09-12 11:15:33	Separate Identity Resolution Into its own worker	**Is your feature request related to a problem? If so, please describe the problem:**\r\nWe resolve identity in the Facade_Worker and the Git_Hub worker, trying to ensure the same people are included in only one row, and identifying aliases. \r\n\r\nUnder initial data load conditions, it becomes a kind of tie breaking order of execution contest that works, but results in extra API calls. \r\n\r\nIt is more optimal to have the identity resolution be its own worker, that is run only after the other workers that gather identity information have completed their initial runs. This way, redundancy is avoided. \r\n	\N	0	2019-10-01 16:45:23	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/386	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/386/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/386/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/386/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/386	open	MDU6SXNzdWU0OTI3NDEyMTA=	492741210	379847	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:07:23	386

336353	25430	277113	336353	336353	2019-09-07 13:14:45	Repo Info Worker: Fix rate limit exceeded error	Should fix #377 \r\n\r\nOn carefully going through the log (https://pastebin.com/pE71B71R), I realized that the worker was trying to go to sleep but couldn't calculate the sleeping time, consequently, raising an exception  (See line no 522 onwards).\r\n\r\nSince the `datetime` module is imported as `from datetime import datetime`, changing `datetime.datetime.now()` to `datetime.now()` and `datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp` to `datetime.fromtimestamp` should allow the worker to calculate the sleeping time and fix this problem.\r\n\r\nAlso, there was a typo [line no: 376] that was raising an exception while the worker tried to handle the previous exception.\r\n\r\nThis PR fixes all these typos and should allow the worker to go to sleep when the rate limit exceeds.	277110	0	2019-09-09 17:37:52	2019-09-09 17:37:52	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/381	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/381/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/381/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/381/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/pull/381	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MzE1MTk1MDk2	490634552	22260291	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:07:27	381

336355	25430	277140	\N	\N	2019-09-04 23:08:13	Augur Single-Platform Target for Developers?	This is more of a discussion than a bug...\r\n\r\n# Developer Platform\r\n\r\nWhile going thru the Augur installation docco, I see references to installing on Mac, on Ubuntu, on Fedora, on Windows...  \r\n\r\nIMHO supporting multiple platforms leads to extra documentation complexity, extra testing, more opportunities for failure. It would simplify things greatly if there were just a single developer installation target.  In this way, the limited developer resources could be spent building features, rather than on platform support.\r\n\r\nMy proposal is to let Ubuntu 18.04 be the target platform for developers, because it has IMO the greatest  market share, and is simplest to set up a VirtualBox devsystem on Windows and Mac.\r\n\r\nIf this proposal is acceptable,  the only item that is impacted would be documentation.  We would simply streamline the documentation to only describe installation on Ubuntu.  If people want to install on other platforms, they would be on their own.\r\n\r\n# Production Platform\r\n\r\nIn my view, Production instances would be deployed as Docker containers, and any platform that supports Docker would be supported.\r\n\r\n# Decision and Possible Follow-on Action\r\n\r\nIf you all are in support of this proposal, then I will submit documentation PR's to streamline the installation docs to refer only to Ubuntu 18.04.\r\n\r\nThanks for your consideration and let me know your views...\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n	277140	4	2019-09-11 19:00:04	2019-09-11 19:00:03	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/379	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/379/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/379/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/379/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/379	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0ODk0NDU5NzE=	489445971	90030	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:07:30	379

(:issue:`1080`)\n> -   Restore the ``response`` argument to :exc:`~exceptions.Unauthorized`.\n>     (:pr:`1527`)\n> -   :exc:`~exceptions.Unauthorized` doesn't add the ``WWW-Authenticate``\n>     header if ``www_authenticate`` is not given. (:issue:`1516`)\n> -   The default URL converter correctly encodes bytes to string rather\n>     than representing them with ``b''``. (:issue:`1502`)\n> -   Fix the filename format string in\n>     :class:`~middleware.profiler.ProfilerMiddleware` to correctly handle\n>     float values. (:issue:`1511`)\n> -   Update :class:`~middleware.lint.LintMiddleware` to work on Python 3.\n>     (:issue:`1510`)\n> -   The debugger detects cycles in chained exceptions and does not time\n>     out in that case. (:issue:`1536`)\n> -   When running the development server in Docker, the debugger security\n>     pin is now unique per container.\n> \n> \n> Version 0.15.2\n> --------------\n> \n> Released 2019-04-02\n> \n> -   ``Rule`` code generation uses a filename that coverage will ignore.\n>     The previous value, "generated", was causing coverage to fail.\n>     (:issue:`1487`)\n> -   The test client removes the cookie header if there are no persisted\n>     cookies. This fixes an issue introduced in 0.15.0 where the cookies\n>     from the original request were used for redirects, causing functions\n>     such as logout to fail. (:issue:`1491`)\n> -   The test client copies the environ before passing it to the app, to\n>     prevent in-place modifications from affecting redirect requests.\n>     (:issue:`1498`)\n> -   The ``"werkzeug"`` logger only adds a handler if there is no handler\n>     configured for its level in the logging chain. This avoids double\n>     logging if other code configures logging first. (:issue:`1492`)\n> \n> \n> Version 0.15.1\n> --------------\n> \n> Released 2019-03-21\n> \n> -   :exc:`~exceptions.Unauthorized` takes ``description`` as the first\n></tr></table> ... (truncated)\n</details>\n<details>\n<summary>Commits</summary>\n\n- [`9b1123a`](https://github.com/pallets/werkzeug/commit/9b1123a779e95b5c38ca911ce1329e87a3348a92) release version 0.15.3\n- 336373	25430	277110	\N	\N	2019-08-25 13:32:46	Simplified Installation for Tech Scenario 1: Local	**Is your feature request related to a problem? If so, please describe the problem:**\r\nAugur has two main parts, and two main technical use scenarios:\r\nPart 1: Back End\r\nPart 2: Front End\r\nTech Scenario 1: New user wanting to try Augur locally\r\nTech Scenario 2: Organization wanting to deploy Augur on a server. \r\n\r\n**Describe the solution you'd like:**\r\nA simple script for local installation. Path execution depending on user answers to questions. \r\n\r\n**Describe alternatives you've considered:**\r\nPath Execution A: (Database)\r\n1. Do you have access to a Postgres 10 or 11 installation, with administrative privileges where you want to install the Augur database? \r\n2. 336406	25430	277111	\N	\N	2017-03-09 20:06:18	Switch/Incorporate Go?	Python is fantastic for what we've been doing so far, which consists of making queries to our GHTorrent database and a Flask API to those queries.\r\n\r\nNow that we are going to begin working on metrics that require analyzing repos, I'm not sure Python+GitPython will meet our needs well. [GitPython](https://github.com/gitpython-developers/GitPython) has a beautiful API but it is probably too slow to make a usable web app that is able to deliver the more complicated metrics without some serious caching. \r\n\r\n[PyGit2](http://www.pygit2.org/) would probably be fast enough for our needs, but then the installation requirements for Windows users would be more involved. We could containerize it, but then we lose the benefits of having a Python library. Also it's GPL, and a modified GPL at that, so I'm not even sure we can use it.\r\n\r\nOne solution is to store every repo we analyze and keep them up to sync, analyzing them when they change and storing the results. Essentially we'd be keeping a database up to date with our metrics. That would allow for practically instant response when users look for a repo, but limit the scope of which repos they can look at, much like http://gittrends.io/\r\n\r\nI think a better solution would be switching to Go.\r\n\r\nI was looking for solutions when I stumbled upon [go-git](https://github.com/src-d/go-git) which is written in Go, and would let us download and manipulate git repos entirely in memory. It is created by a company that is doing some ML stuff on the code from every GitHub repo out there, so it was made to tackle a problem similar to ours. We would still cache, and we'd likely want to still download large/popular repos to avoid re-downloading them over and over, but for smaller, more obscure repos our Go package could download them and analyze them in seconds. The entire GitHub ecosystem would be open to our users, while still being practical for us and fast for them. \r\n\r\nWe would also get the other benefits of Go, including easy cross-platform binaries with no dependencies, and much better general performance vs Python. This would make it trivial for our users to host their own ghdata or use it behind firewalls.\r\n\r\nThe disadvantage is that go-git doesn't have close to the same breadth as GitPython, so we'd have to reimplement a lot of GoPython's functionality. One important example is it lacks `git blame`\r\n\r\nWhat do you all think? \r\n\r\nIf Go is not an option, any thoughts on the best way to deal with the slowness of GitPython? 	277111	13	2018-09-19 00:26:35	2017-04-07 21:18:01	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/28	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/28/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/28/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/28/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/28	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyMTMxNDk1Mjk=	213149529	835856	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:08:22	28

version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor/major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)\n- `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)\n- `@dependabot use these labels` will set the current labels as the default for future PRs for this repo and language\n- `@dependabot use these reviewers` will set the current reviewers as the default for future PRs for this repo and language\n- `@dependabot use these assignees` will set the current assignees as the default for future PRs for this repo and language\n- `@dependabot use this milestone` will set the current milestone as the default for future PRs for this repo 336409	25430	277116	\N	\N	2017-02-20 18:54:22	License Information Metric	Update on search for ways to get license information:\r\n\r\nI looked into DoSOCSv2 for license information.  It examines project files that are present locally.  We would have to download a project's files from GitHub in order to run something similar.  I think it might be technically possible to download the files automatically.  We could use the API's contents to get the download URL https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/contents/#get-contents and then download using that URL.  However, I'm not sure downloading and storing entire projects, even temporarily, would be viable in terms of speed and storage.\r\n\r\nAs far as I can tell, DoSOCSv2 uses https://github.com/ardumont/fossology-nomossa to examine files for license information.  Fossology lists the following as things it uses.  The top two would appear to scan files for license information (though I haven't looked in depth into either Nomos or Monk).\r\n\r\n    Nomos, a license scanner based in regular expressions.\r\n    Monk, a license scanner based on text comparison.\r\n    MonkBulk, an extension to Monk for user-based phase searching.\r\n    Copyright, an Agent searching for copyright, URL, e-mail and authorship statements.\r\n    ECC, export control and customs as an extension to Copyright.\r\n    Package Agent, an agent exporting metadata from installation packages.\r\n    Maintenance Agent, (new in 2.4.0)\r\n    Mimetype Agent, running over files trying to determine the mimetype.\r\n    Buckets, an agent to categorize files based un user-defineable definitions.\r\n\r\n	277111	16	2018-10-12 04:17:04	2018-10-12 04:17:04	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/25	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/25/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/25/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/25/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/25	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyMDg5NTg2MjA=	208958620	17164838	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:08:28	25
336410	25430	277116	\N	\N	2017-02-20 18:42:12	Security Metric	Update on Security Metric search:\r\n\r\nI looked into cii-census project on Github.  It calculates and assigns a point value for security (more information here: https://www.coreinfrastructure.org/programs/census-project).  By reverse-engineering I found the data it gets does appear to be obtained manually (for example, through the command line) and from the Debian security tracker website, so I'm not sure we could follow the same procedures other than perhaps assigning some sort of point values.\r\n\r\nThey mention the following sources for their data:\r\n"The data represented here is derived from: DSAs issued by the Security Team; issues tracked in the CVE database, issues tracked in the National Vulnerability Database (NVD), maintained by NIST; and security issues discovered in Debian packages as reported in the BTS."\r\n\r\nAs far as CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures), what I have found when reading about them is that they appear to be voluntary to register.  In other words, more CVEs for a project may indicate acceptance of CVEs as the standard, greater ability to detect vulnerabilities, and/or more reporting rather than less security.  \r\n\r\nI did find this site that gives a CVE count for various products https://www.cvedetails.com/product-list/firstchar-M/vendor_id-0/products.html .  As of now I'm not sure of a way to use it other than manually, though.\r\n\r\nThe National Vulnerability Database also keeps track of vulnerabilities.  I have not looked into it in depth.\r\n\r\nIn short, as of when I write this I have not found a clear way to evaluate security of a Github project or discover how many CVE's it has automatically.   \r\n\r\nI do know that there are automated tools that can attack a running web application and create a results report based on any vulnerabilities, but that would require us manually installing and running our own copy of a web project (so, not viable).	277111	6	2018-10-12 04:16:05	2018-10-12 04:16:05	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/24	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/24/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/24/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/24/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/24	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyMDg5NTY1NzE=	208956571	17164838	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:08:31	24
336411	25430	277116	\N	\N	2017-02-16 20:54:52	Documentation	Good practices in documentation will help our code to be maintainable over the long run.  It also allows for better teamwork and easier contribution from outside users.\r\n\r\n1.  Comments.  We should have comments explaining what each part of the code is doing and why.  This helps both new contributors and ourselves to remember or understand the code.  Comments also need to be kept up-to-date with the code, that way they match what is actually happening.\r\n\r\n2.  Clean code.  While when initially solving a problem we may end up with code that is messy and hard to read, we should strive to clean up the code such that it is as self-explanatory as possible.  This includes but is not limited to intuitive variable names, good formatting, and refactoring (with tests) to make code easier to follow when necessary.\r\n\r\n3.  Unit tests.  While the main purpose of unit tests is to determine whether something is working and detect breaking changes, they can also be a form of documentation.  If a unit test is complete, well-written, and up-to-date with the code it refers to, it shows the reader what are the expected results of running a particular piece of the code.	277110	2	2017-12-18 17:26:19	2017-12-18 17:26:18	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/23	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/23/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/23/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/23/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/23	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyMDgyNDM0NDQ=	208243444	17164838	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:08:32	23

336430	25430	277110	\N	\N	2017-01-23 18:00:23	Technical Progress General Inquiry	Hi everyone:\r\n\r\n@bkeepers @howderek @wingr especially: \r\n\r\nI am writing to give you an overview of the technical progress we are making, and to foreshadow future requests for accelerated or privileged access to the GitHub API that we may request. There are headings below so you can scan.\r\n\r\n### BACKGROUND (We All hopefully share this now for the most part): \r\n\r\nLooking at changes over time in GitHub repositories will be essential to the aims of our project:  understanding their health and sustainability. We hypothesize (and, based on preliminary work, we think with some likelihood that we are right) the following:\r\n\r\n1. **H1:** There is a relationship between derivable indicators of repository activity on GitHub and the type of organization governing the project\r\n2. **H2:** There is a relationship between derivable indicators of repository activity on GitHub and performance, as perceived from the perspective of various stakeholders.\r\n3. **H3:** Different stakeholders (owners, contributors, users, regulators, etc.) will be influenced by different combinations of indicators. \r\n\r\nI think these flow as lower level operating tests from our research questions: \r\n\r\n1. How and to what extent are community health and sustainability indicators identifiable from GitHub open source community data?\r\n2. What are dominant genres of community based on health and sustainability indicators, and how and to what extent are health and sustainability indicators different between these communities?\r\n3. How and to what extent are health and sustainability indicators understood by community owners and other stakeholders?\r\n4. How and to what extent do heath and sustainability indicators change over time as communities evolve to include increased membership, new governance structures, and support from foundations? \r\n\r\n### TECHNICAL APPROACH: \r\n\r\nHere, to some extent, we are looking to Brandon and Rowan to validate that we are not missing any key concepts or attributes of the available resources from GitHub. In particular, if there are limitations in the data archives and torrents we are referencing, those would be good to be aware of. \r\n\r\n1. We are doing our indicator development against GHTorrent and the GitHub Archive.\r\n    1. Since data about deleted repositories and users may play a role in our research, it's necessary to use archives of GitHub data as opposed to the timestamp information included in GitHub API requests.\r\n    2. From our initial exploration, it appears there will be two projects that will meet our needs, GHTorrent and GitHub Archive\r\n    3. GHTorrent provides a SQL database of metadata created from the events stream, and GitHub Archive archives those events themselves.\r\n    4. There is a lot of overlap between the datasets, but both are needed. A fast interface to the data is needed, such as the SQL database that is populated by GHTorrent. \r\n\r\n2. Once indicators are mature enough to evaluate (estimated 4-6 weeks), we will need more current information to validate with project stakeholders, who will likely have less recall of things going on a month or two ago than last week. We think less archival indicators are also going to be more compelling for GitHub users generally. To that end,\r\n    1. The data we use will need to become quite “up to date”. What is the best strategy?\r\n        1. Daily dumps provided by the GitHub Archive to fill in the gaps between the SQL backups provided by GHTorrent and the realtime data provided by the GitHub API?\r\n        1. Privileged API Access?\r\n        1. Both?\r\n        1. Other?\r\n    2. Ideally, we would like to demonstrate indicators and provide an indicator exploration site with the hope of prototyping a system that could be used to gain wider evaluation of the indicators (from GitHub’s ecosystem).\r\n\r\nPerhaps this is too much for an email and a call is warranted?  But I thought I would start here!\r\n\r\nThanks!	277111	6	2018-09-19 00:26:34	2017-05-11 15:45:33	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/4	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/4/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/4/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/4/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/4	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyMDI2MDY4NTg=	202606858	379847	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:08:54	4
336419	25430	277116	\N	\N	2017-02-08 20:14:05	Best way to determine organization diversity for a project	I created a few queries earlier that counts the number of organizations or companies (they are separate concepts in the data) with pull requests on a project.\r\n\r\nHowever, I have been looking more into some of the GHTorrent tables today and found that a user can be a member of multiple organizations.  So if user Jane made a pull request, and Jane is a member of 4 different organizations, do we want to count 4 organizations towards diversity for that single pull request?  Organizations have unique ids, so it is clear which users are members of which organizations (as compared to companies, described below).  Organizations may not match one-to-one with real world companies.  "Google" is a separate organization from "Google Drive", "Google Page Speed" and "Google Cloud Platform"\r\n\r\nThere is another field we can use to determine such diversity, the "company" field.  Each user can have only one company.  However, looking at the data in this field, I think users can type whatever they want into it.  Thus, there are users whose company is "Google Inc.", others whose company is "Google, Inc.", and also those whose company is "Google".\r\n\r\nWhat do others think about how to decide which user is a member of which organization or company?\r\n\r\n1.  Should we be using organizations or companies?  I think organizations may be better due to unique ids.  It is clear which users are members of which organizations, less so with companies.  However, neither seems to match one-to-one with companies as we would normally think of them.\r\n2.  If a user is a member of multiple organizations, do we count them all when a user contributes to a project?\r\n3.  If a user is determined to not be a member of an organization or company (through whatever method we use) do we assume they are independent and count independent users as an organization/company?	277111	20	2018-10-12 04:18:16	2018-10-12 04:18:16	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/15	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/15/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/15/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/15/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/15	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyMDYzMTExOTU=	206311195	17164838	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:08:42	15

336427	25430	277152	\N	\N	2017-01-26 15:08:50	Github Health Categories and Metrics Suggestions	Hello Everyone,\r\n\r\nIn working with @germonprez in his class at the University of Nebraska Omaha, I was asked to identify categories and some metrics associated with them. He suggested posting this here for discussion. \r\n\r\nWhen presented with this problem I first took a step back and looked at how repositories flourish on Github. It is important to note that the code itself is not the only thing of concern. The goal here is to address and rank repositories on what the user is concerned about. From this I derive five key areas that I named:\r\n•\tCommunity – Active contributors to the Repository and their growth and activity.\r\n•\tCode – Quality and reliability of the source code itself.\r\n•\tAssistance – Quality and helpfulness of issue resolution.\r\n•\tAdaptability – The ability for the code to have a variety of uses.\r\n•\tLicensing – Usability of the code.\r\n\r\nIt is important to segregate these concerns and have the ability to judge them separately as this should help diversify the systems adaptiveness to varying concerns. An entity that only plans on using source internally may not need to consider the license but is concerned about the quality of the code and community to support that code.\r\n\r\nCommunity refers to the active contributors that support a repository. Looking at the activity of each contributor both on the repository and then on Github in general to determine how much time they commit to the repo compared to other projects. This should also look at the interaction, closeness and growth of the contributors over time. A few metrics that would apply to this are:\r\n•\tnumber of contributors\r\n•\tfrequency of contributions\r\n•\tactivity level of contributors\r\n•\tTruck Factor (“The number of developers it would need to lose to destroy its progress.” From the Influence Analysis of Github Repositories)\r\n•\tTime to become contributor\r\n•\tDistribution of work across community\r\n•\trate of acceptance of new contributions\r\n\r\nCode is probably the easiest category and the hardest category to evaluate. Ideally, we want to know that it is routinely kept up to date, is clean and well documented, and will continue to stay that way for the foreseeable future. This is easier said than done, one thing that makes it easier to analyze is the fact that it has the most meta data to work with. A few metrics that would apply are:\r\n•\tnumber of updates\r\n•\tregularity of updates\r\n•\ttime since last update\r\n•\tnumber of pull rejections\r\n•\tnumber of CVEs and % of age open – https://www.coreinfrastructure.org/programs/census-project\r\n•\t3rd party Dependencies (if obtainable) – https://www.coreinfrastructure.org/programs/census-project\r\n•\tstars\r\n•\toverall size of the repository / commits\r\n\r\nAssistance is exactly what it sounds like. As a user of the code how much assistance can you get in implementing it. Additionally, while this may not be directly relevant to some entities, it is indirectly relevant to everyone. Lack of support leads to lower adoption which also leads to a smaller set of stakeholders willing to keep it going. A few metrics that would apply are:\r\n•\tnumber of open issues / label \r\n•\ttime to close\r\n•\tcommunication level (response time and number)\r\n\r\nAdaptability refers to the degree that the project could be easily adapted to your specific needs. While this is very useful it’s also extremely hard to determine from the metrics. However, I believe a couple could give small indirect indications of flexibility. The first is the number of forks in the repository followed by the number of downloads. A large number of forks with lower downloads tend indicate a useful code that can be expanded upon in many ways. Where a low number of forks but large number of downloads may indicate a project that is specific but widely useful. More research will need to be done to identify and refine these assumptions.\r\n\r\nLicensing which is in reference to the usability of the code. More restrictive licenses may be a turn off or may just require more adaptability and community to be viable. A couple metrics for licenses would be:\r\n•\tIs there a license\r\n•\tNumber of licenses\r\n•\tFlexibility of licenses\r\n	277126	2	2018-09-19 00:26:35	2017-01-27 14:34:29	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/7	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/7/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/7/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/7/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/7	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyMDMzOTUwNzU=	203395075	14626151	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:08:51	7

336464	25430	277123	336464	336464	2018-04-25 20:42:58	Make updates for Linux	I spoke to @sgoggins about `make install-dev` on Linux. I only have the first change so far, but there are 2 more outstanding issues I want to address.\r\nThe first is installing it in a Python venv. In this case the venv takes over pip for one version of python, but `make install-dev` tries to install dependencies for both Python 2 & 3. Should this be addressed via separate build targets for Python 2 & 3 or is there a way of determining if python is running inside venv.\r\nThe second issue is `npm install -g apidoc brunch yarn`. This command requires root permission to run, which should be avoided ideally. My current solution is to omit the `-g` flag, installing the modules locally, but they don't appear on the path and can't be run as easily. I don't have an elegant solution for that particular problem.	277111	1	2018-09-19 00:26:37	2018-05-01 21:04:34	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/99	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/99/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/99/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/99/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/pull/99	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTg0MTU3NjUy	317786492	16946799	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:09:30	99

336472	25430	277110	\N	\N	2018-03-14 21:59:29	Metrics Functionality Expansion: Timeliness Focused Metrics	One metrics area we would like to track are SLAs, e.g. how timely issues and pull requests are being handled. The beeswarm visualizations we now have show individual events, but I think there is a use case for a summarized metric. This requires some further thinking to define how it should be calculated and visualized. A couple challenges concerning this on the backend and frontend:\r\n\r\n- Events can span longer than a "group_by" (week, month, year) period and up to the present time, and a sensible, understandable method of slotting events should be selected.\r\n- Response/resolution times should be shown in the context of the number of events in order to afford conclusions about the aggregated data (especially when events are sparse).	277111	1	2018-04-09 22:37:24	2018-04-09 22:37:24	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/91	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/91/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/91/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/91/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/91	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzMDUzNDQzMTc=	305344317	379847	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:09:37	91

336479	25430	277112	\N	\N	2018-03-02 23:22:44	New Visualization Candidates - Feedback Needed	We have identified several candidates for new visualizations. Feedback is encouraged! These are not listed in any sort of order.\r\n\r\n## Metrics Visualizations\r\n1. [Calendar](https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4063318): Total commits to project per day over the user-specified time period. Similar to GitHub's own implementation for a single user.\r\n2. [Stacked Graph](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/3943967): Issues Resolved, Closed, Opened w/ activity, Opened w/o activity grouped by month\r\n3. [Bubble Chart](https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4063269): Two Possible Implementations\r\n    #### Implementation 1:\r\n   -Each contributor gets their own bubble. This bubble is then shaded with varying hues of red, yellow, \r\n  and blue to give it a specific color. These hues are dependent on the following metrics: \r\n   -Red: Count of Issues Created + Count of Issues Commented On\r\n   -Blue: Count of Pull Requests Created + Count of Pull Requests Commented On\r\n   -Yellow: Count of Commits + Count of Commits Commented On\r\n   -The size of this bubble would be dependent on the total number of all of the above metrics.\r\n    #### Implementation 2:\r\n     -Each contributor gets their own bubble. This bubble is then shaded with varying hues of red, \r\n  yellow, and blue to give it a specific color. These hues are dependent on the following metrics: \r\n   -Red: Count of Total Issue Comments\r\n   -Blue: Count of Total Pull Request Comments\r\n   -Yellow: Count of Total Commit Comments\r\n   -The size of this bubble would be dependent on the total number of all of the above metrics. In addition, if the contributor had forked the project, this would be denoted by a border of some sort.\r\n \r\n   -We have also considered implementing both of these side by side and allowing the user to switch between them at will. Ideally, the transition would be animated and a user could track various contributors during the switch.\r\n\r\n4. [Chord Diagram](https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4062006): Each segment is a project with some arbitrary size requirement and a dominant language (i.e. 100 contributors, 200 commits, Python). The width of the connection between segments represents the number of contributors that have contributed to both projects.\r\n5. [Parallel Coordinates](https://mbostock.github.io/d3/talk/20111116/iris-parallel.html): Issue Count vs. Issue Comments vs. Issue Commenters vs. Issue Volume\r\n6. [Deficit Graph (technical name unknown)](http://www.brightpointinc.com/united-states-trade-deficit/): Code insertions/deletions on a month by month basis, attributed to contributors\r\n7. [Pie Chart](https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/3887235): All project Issues or PRs that have been Opened/Closed/Reopened or Merged/No action yet ([related: dual Pie Chart / Line Graph](https://codepen.io/stefanjudis/full/gkHwJ))\r\n8. [Network Graph](http://www.cotrino.com/2012/11/language-network/): Show communication between commenters by issue. Thickness of connections = log(# of communications between the two contributors), Size of node = # of total communications for that contributor\r\n\r\n\r\n## Other Visualizations\r\n1. [Cluster Dendrogram](https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4063570): Dependency Tree, grouped by project type (i.e. package, framework, website, developer tool, etc)\r\n2. [Radial Tidy Tree](https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4063550): Dependency tree, grouped by project type (i.e. package, framework, website, developer tool, etc)\r\n\r\n	277112	0	2018-07-17 00:34:31	2018-07-17 00:34:31	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/84	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/84/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/84/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/84/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/84	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzMDE5MzcwODk=	301937089	31522931	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:09:44	84

336481	25430	277110	\N	\N	2018-02-27 13:59:00	Google Summer of Code Ideas	[ This issue for addressing questions and comments related to this GSoC idea, which is one of the ideas proposed by the [CHAOSS group for the 2018 edition of GSoC](https://wiki.linuxfoundation.org/chaoss/gsoc-ideas) ]\r\n\r\nCurrently, GHData includes a backend, written in Python, and a Front End, written in javascript using the Mozilla metrics.js library and other D3 based tools for visualization.  The purpose of the system is to test out new metrics and new metrics visualizations for the CHAOSS project.  \r\n\r\nExamples and descriptions of the visualizations can be found here: https://goo.gl/2DPuc2\r\n\r\nThe aims of the project are as follows:\r\n\r\nGHData is an open source software project that is developing as part of the CHAOSS project through our work in 2017. It fills an important technology niche not addressed by other analytics tools within the CHAOSS project. GHData is focused on building human-centered open source software health metrics, defined by collaborations of the CHAOSS project and other open source stakeholders. GHData is software focused on making sense of data using four key human-centered data science strategies:\r\n1.\tEnable comparisons. People navigate complex unknowns analogically. Let folks see how their project compares with others they are familiar with.\r\n2.\tMake time a fundamental dimension in all metrics. Point in time scores are useful. They are more useful if we can see how they compare historically and can be used to anticipate a trajectory.\r\n3.\tThe provenance from raw data to metrics visualization is transparent.\r\n4.\tEnable downloadable visualizations as a .csv, .svg, or other data exchange format. This is because (a) people trust metrics when they can see the underlying data and (b) proving traceability back to the CHAOSS project's metrics standards requires easy transparency.\r\n\r\nWriting Python code to query the GHTorrent databases (request credentials privately, through the mailing list) and obtain from it the metrics relevant for the report. Possible technologies to achieve this aim include Python Pandas and javascript. \r\n\r\nWe are currently focused on building out new metrics and new forms of metrics visualizations.  [An alpha copy of the deployed software can be found here](http://ghdata.sociallycompute.io)\r\n\r\n__Difficulty__: easy/medium\r\n__Requirements__: Python programming. Interest in software analytics. Willingness to understand GHData internals. Interest in javascript and SQL are also valuable. \r\n\r\n__Recommended__: Experience with Python interfaces to databases would be convenient, but can be learned during the project. Experience with Latex and/or Python Jupyter Notebooks would help.\r\nMentors: @sgoggins, @jgbarah , @germonprez , @jcabot\r\n\r\n**Microtasks**\r\ndo\r\n\r\nOnce you're familiar with installing the docker image or downloading the development framework: \r\n\r\nMicrotask 1: Produce a new visualization for any of the existing metrics you find implemented under the ghdata directory.  Sources for GHTorrent, the GitHub API and Libraries.io are implemented. \r\n\r\nMicrotask 2: Produce a chart showing the distribution of time-to-close (using the corresponding field in the GHTorrent database) for issues already closed, and opened during the last six months.\r\n\r\nMicrotask 3: Produce a listing of repositories, as a table and as CSV file, with the number of commits authored, issues opened, and pull requests opened, during the last three months, ordered by the total number (commits plus issues plus pull requests).\r\n\r\nMicrotask 4: Perform any other analysis you may find interesting, based on GHData's Python collectors/API access programs. \r\n\r\nIf you want, you can also:\r\n\r\nMicrotask 5: Produce a pull request for GHData and try to follow instructions until it gets accepted. Try do do something simple that you consider useful, not necessarily fix to the code: improvement of comments, documentation or testing will usually be easier to get accepted, and very useful for the project. Please, avoid just producing a random pull request just to have another microtask: the objective is not that you get one more microtask done, but that you understand how to interact with developers in the project contributing with something that could be useful).\r\nOf course, there is no need to do all the microtasks, you only need to show that your skills are in good standing for working in this project.\r\n\r\nShowing the work you did\r\nIf you want to show the work you did, open a GitHub repository, and upload to it:\r\n\r\nA README.md file explaining what you did, and linking to the results (which will be in the same repository, see below). This will be the main file to show your skills and interest on the project, so try to make it organized and clear, in a way that we can easily understand what you did.\r\n\r\nScreenshots of the dashboard(s) you produced, and configuration files you used for them (if any). Please remember removing passwords and/or auth tokens that could be in them, before uploading. In the REAME.md file, link all those files, telling about which GitHub projects you analyzed.\r\n\r\nPython scripts you produced, with enough information (in comments and/or in the README.md file) so that we can run them if needed. Upload Python scripts ready to work assuming GHData is already installed. \r\n\r\nLinks to the pull request you did (if any), along with any comment you may have about it.\r\n\r\n[Contributing to GHData](https://github.com/OSSHealth/ghdata/tree/master/docs)\r\n\r\n[CHAOSS Metrics (work in progress)](https://wiki.linuxfoundation.org/chaoss/metrics#chaoss-oss-project-metrics)\r\n\r\nAsking for help\r\nIf you need help, please use the following channels.\r\n\r\nFor issues related to GrimoireLab:\r\n\r\n[#chaoss-community channel in Freenode IRC](https://freenode.net/)\r\n\r\n[CHAOSS mailing list](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/mailman/listinfo/oss-health-metrics)	277110	7	2018-09-19 00:26:37	2018-06-14 02:12:11	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/82	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/82/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/82/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/82/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/82	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzMDA2NDEwOTA=	300641090	379847	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:09:45	82

(Project start date – today’s date)\r\nTotal Commits | Total   number of commits to the project within the analyzed period of time.\r\nDistinct Committers | Total   number of unique committers within the analyzed period of time.\r\nTotal Closed Issues | A total   number of closed issues within the analyzed period of time.\r\nPull Request Duration | Average (Mean/Median)*   duration of days of all the unique   users who have made pull request within the analyzed period of time.   Calculated as (user duration = first pull request date – last pull request   date).\r\nPull Request Comment Duration | Average (Mean/Median)* duration of days of all the pull request comments from unique users who have made pull request comments within the analyzed period   of time. Calculated as (duration = first pull request comment date – last   pull request comment date).\r\nCommits Duration | Average (Mean/Median)* duration   of days of all the commits by unique users who have made commits within the   analyzed period of time. Calculated as (duration = first commit date – last   commit date).\r\nIssue Comments Duration | Average (Mean/Median)* duration of days of all the comments a unique   user have   made on an issue within the analyzed period of time. Calculated as (duration   = first issue comment date – last issue comment date).\r\nTotal   Watchers | Total number of   watchers (subscribers) to a project.\r\n \r\nReward Metrics from GH   Torrent:\r\nPull request accepted duration | Average (Mean/Median)* duration of days of all the users made the pull request and their request   has been accepted within the analyzed period of time.\r\nPull request rejected duration | Average (Mean/Median)* duration of days of all the users made the pull request and their request   has been rejected within the analyzed period of time.\r\nAverage Pull Request Comments | Average (Mean/Median)* number of comments on one single   pull request of the focal project within the analyzed period of time.\r\n \r\nImpact Metrics from Libraries.io\r\nUpstream Dependencies | Number of other   projects that depend on the focal project.\r\nDownstream Dependencies | Number of other   projects the focal project depends on.\r\n\r\n	277110	5	2019-01-24 17:52:35	2019-01-24 17:52:35	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/76	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/76/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/76/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/76/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/76	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyOTY1NTgxMjM=	296558123	379847	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:09:54	76

336529	25430	277116	\N	\N	2017-03-20 18:05:14	Organization History	organizationHistory folder is now added under dev branch.  It contains the pythonBlameHistoryTree.py file, which gets the percentage of a repo written by different organizations at the time of each commit.  If no organizations are output for a certain commit, or the percentage adds up to less than 100%, this is expected because not all users are a member of an organization.\r\n\r\nHowever, currently the way users are matched to organizations, it is possible to have a user be a member of multiple organizations (leading to a potential sum of more than 100% of the repo, and/or other misleading statistics).\r\n\r\nData for the percentage of the file comes from Git.  The Git Blame command allows the user to view which user most recently changed each line of code in a file.  By looping through every commit and every file in the repo, we can get a percentage of the repo written by each user over the history of the repo.\r\n\r\nThe user's organization is obtained through querying the ghTorrent database using the user's email address (in my local case, MSR14).  	277110	1	2019-01-24 17:52:35	2019-01-24 17:52:35	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/34	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/34/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/34/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/34/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/34	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyMTU1MDczMTE=	215507311	17164838	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:10:37	34

336559	25430	277112	\N	\N	2018-12-18 00:45:21	Increase robustness of error handling	**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**\r\nWhen connecting to a database that has no data, the following error is thrown: \r\n<img width="512" alt="screen shot 2018-12-17 at 6 20 27 pm" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31522931/50124463-5174c580-022a-11e9-8f24-4cf488f13662.png">\r\n\r\nThis error is not indicative of the actual problem (which is that the database is empty) and could lead to confusion and time wasted trying a debug an error that does not actually exist.\r\n\r\n**Describe the solution you'd like**\r\nThere should be more robust error handling so that problems are more transparent.\r\n\r\n**Describe alternatives you've considered**\r\nGenerally, I don't think should be alternatives to this: if something went fatally wrong, the user should be told exactly what went wrong.\r\n\r\n**Additional context**\r\nThis will likely require more than just the simple addition of a few try/except blocks, and instead will likely mean more heavy refactoring. 336578	25430	277121	\N	\N	2018-10-23 22:47:14	Specify Content Language	**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**\r\nTo conform to web accessibility standards, we need to declare the content language of our page to allow screen readers to more easily access our page.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe problem is described more formally as such:  \r\n\r\n>Developers should define the natural language of a document to ensure that screen readers and other user agents understand the language the document is to be interpreted in.  Specifically, when a document contains multiple inline language choices, screen readers and other assistive technology types must know what the default language type is to ensure they can appropriately switch between languages. \r\nPer the HTML 4.01 recommendation, language declarations should be made in accordance with IETF RFC 1766.\r\n\r\n>Always declare the default language for text in the page using attributes on the html tag. \r\n><ul>\r\n><li>Do NOT use the meta element with the content attribute set to Content-Language.</li> \r\n><li>Use language attributes rather than HTTP to declare the default language for 'text processing' (ie. >when language needs to be known for things such as font choice, styling, spell-checking, hyphentation, quote mark styling, etc.). </li>\r\n><li>Do not declare the default language of a document in the body element, use the html element. \r\n><li>Where a document contains content aimed at speakers of more than one language, decide whether you want to declare one language in the html tag, or leave the languages undefined until later. ></li>\r\n><li>Where a document contains content aimed at speakers of more than one language, try to divide the document linguistically at the highest possible level, and declare the appropriate language for each of those divisions. </li>\r\n><li>For HTML use the lang attribute only, for XHTML 1.0 served as text/html use the lang and xml:lang attributes, and for XHTML served as XML use the xml:lang attribute only. </li>\r\n></ul>\r\n\r\n**Describe the solution you'd like**\r\nAdding a lang tag to the <html> header i.e. `<html lang="en">`\r\n\r\n**Additional context**\r\nSource: https://webaccessibility.com/results using twitter.augurlabs.io\r\n	277110	2	2018-11-11 17:08:50	2018-11-11 17:08:50	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/185	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/185/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/185/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/185/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/185	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzNzMyMzM5MjY=	373233926	23271436	GitHub 336636	25430	277110	\N	\N	2019-07-18 16:20:39	API Endpoint Request	#### Calculate Contributions and Display Developers Contributing n % of all Commits (Repo and Repo Group) \r\nWe want to build a pie chart that shows the commit share of the developers "inside the bus factor", and then provides a slice, as well, for "all other committers". \r\n1. To orient ourselves, first, how many total commits are there? \r\n```sql\r\n    select sum(patches) from (select repo_group_id, email, year, patches from dm_repo_group_annual\r\n    where year = 2017\r\n    order by patches desc)a; \r\n```\r\nFor our example, there are 9,671 patches in a repository group of 112 repositories.\r\n\r\n2.  What is the distribution of committers and total commits? \r\n```sql\r\n    SELECT\r\n        repo_group_id,\r\n        email,\r\n        SUM ( patches ) as commitsyear \r\n    FROM\r\n        ( SELECT repo_group_id, email, YEAR, patches FROM dm_repo_group_annual WHERE YEAR = 2017 ORDER BY patches DESC )  a\r\n    GROUP BY\r\n        repo_group_id,\r\n        email\r\n        order by commitsyear desc; \r\n```\r\nThere are 783 committers in our sample. The top committer has 650 commits, the bottom committer has 1 commit, and there are 411 such individuals. \r\n\r\n3. How many committers are in the set that contributes 50% of the 9,671 commits. \r\n    - We know the total commits are 9,671, so we need to loop through committers in an ordered list, from the top down, until we arrive at the list of top contributors who contribute 50% of the total commits. In this case,  `1/2*9,671 = 4,835.5`, and we round up to 4,836. \r\n    - When we loop through top committers, keeping a cumulative total, we add each developer to the list until we exceed 4,836, at which point we have the list. There are 30 committers in our list (plus one row for everyone not in the "developers with the most contributions whose total commits add up to 50% (or other percent) of the total): \r\n```\r\n        Developer           Commits in a Year\r\n  \r\n```\r\n4. Our pie chart would then have 30 developers, and a 31st slice for "all other contributors". This is a large case, obviously. Perhaps a percentile that is lower would be appropriate. This is parameterizable. \r\n**Pseudo Code: \r\n```python\r\n    commits =1; \r\n    for i in all_committers: \r\n        commits = commits+developerCommits\r\n        developerlist = add developer to list; \r\n        if commits > totalcommits/2 \r\n            break; \r\n```\r\nThe end result we want is a list with the commits per developer until we reach 1/2 or some other share of the total commits PLUS, one slice for ALL the other commits made by people outside the group whose commit total, counted from the most commits down, adds up to that percentage (50% or otherwise). \r\n\r\n5. The JSON we would want to return probably looks like: \r\n```json\r\n    [\r\n        {\r\n            "user_id": 1,\r\n            "email": "s@goggins.com",\r\n            "commits": 333,\r\n            "repo_group_name": "rails",\r\n            "repo_group_id": 21000\r\n        },\r\n        {\r\n            "user_id": 2,\r\n            "email": "d@goggins.com",\r\n            "commits": 331,\r\n            "repo_group_name": "rails",\r\n            "repo_group_id": 21000\r\n        },\r\n        {\r\n            "user_id": 1,\r\n            "email": "other_contributors",\r\n            "commits": 133,\r\n            "repo_group_name": "rails",\r\n            "repo_group_id": 21000\r\n        }\r\n    ]\r\n\r\n```	\N	3	2019-09-03 13:06:24	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/327	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/327/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/327/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/327/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/327	open	MDU6SXNzdWU0Njk4NjUwNTQ=	469865054	379847	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:12:34	327

336640	25430	277113	336640	336640	2019-07-11 15:50:16	Make gh_repo_info_worker compatible with broker	In this version of the gh_repo_info_worker the worker connects to the broker and can receive tasks.\r\n\r\nYou can run the worker using the command `python -m gh_repo_info_worker.runtime` while in the `workers/gh_repo_info_worker` directory.\r\n\r\nTo send a task to this worker send a `POST` request to the endpoint `/task` with the following json data:\r\n```{\r\n  "job_type": "UPDATE",\r\n  "models": [\r\n    "repo_info"\r\n  ],\r\n  "given": {\r\n    "git_url": "https://github.com/rails/rails-dom-testing.git"\r\n  }\r\n}\r\n```\r\nThe `git_url` field specifies the git repository you want to run the worker on.\r\n\r\nSigned-off-by: Parth Sharma <parth261297@gmail.com>	277109	0	2019-07-11 15:59:17	2019-07-11 15:59:17	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/323	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/323/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/323/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/323/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/pull/323	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0Mjk2NzE3MTc5	466974378	22260291	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:12:38	323

336642	25430	277110	\N	\N	2019-07-04 20:04:26	Worker Update to Capture Additional Issue Metadata	To speed up our integrity checking via the Housekeeper process, the following pieces of data are requested from the GitHub Issue Worker. These are fields already added to the test schema, and we would like them populated by the next version of the worker. \r\n\r\n# Columns Added to Issue Related Schema to Incorporate into GitHub Worker\r\n\r\n## issue_msg_ref:\r\n\t- COMMENT ON COLUMN "augur_data"."issue_msg_ref"."issue_msg_ref_src_comment_id" IS 'This ID comes from the source. In the case of GitHub, it is the id that is the first field returned from the issue comments API';\r\n\t- COMMENT ON COLUMN "augur_data"."issue_msg_ref"."issue_msg_ref_src_node_id" IS 'This character based identifier comes from the source. In the case of GitHub, it is the id that is the first field returned from the issue comments API';\r\n\r\n## issue_events : \r\n\t- COMMENT ON COLUMN "augur_data"."issue_events"."issue_event_id" IS 'This ID comes from the source. In the case of GitHub, it is the id that is the first field returned from the issue events API';\r\n   \r\n## issue_labels: \r\n    - COMMENT ON COLUMN "public"."issue_labels"."label_src_id" IS 'This ID comes from the source. In the case of GitHub, it is the id that is the first field returned from the issue events API JSON subsection for issues.';\r\n    - COMMENT ON COLUMN "public"."issue_labels"."label_src_id" IS 'This character based identifier (node) comes from the source. In the case of GitHub, it is the id that is the second field returned from the issue events API JSON subsection for issues. ';\r\n\r\n## issue_assignees: \r\n    - COMMENT ON COLUMN "augur_data"."issue_assignees"."issue_assignee_src_id" IS 'This ID comes from the source. In the case of GitHub, it is the id that is the first field returned from the issue events API in the issue_assignees embedded JSON object. We may discover it is an ID for the person themselves; but my hypothesis is that its not.';\r\n    - COMMENT ON COLUMN "augur_data"."issue_assignees"."issue_assignee_src_node" IS 'This character based identifier comes from the source. 336679	25430	277113	336679	336679	2019-05-28 18:44:41	Implement 'code_changes' metric	Implemented '[code_changes](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/blob/master/metrics/Code_Changes.md)' metric with the following optional parameters:\r\n\r\n- period: \r\n    - Specifies the periodicity. \r\n    - Can be set to 'day', 'week', 'month' or 'year'. \r\n    - Defaults to 'day'\r\n- begin_date: \r\n    - Specifies the beginning date. \r\n    - Possible values: '2018', '2018-05', '2019-05-01', ..., ' 2017-03-02 05:34:19'\r\n    - Defaults to '1970-1-1 0:0:0'\r\n- end_date:\r\n    - Specifies the ending date.\r\n    - Possible values: '2018', '2018-05', '2019-05-01', ..., ' 2017-03-02 05:34:19'\r\n    - Defaults to the current date and time\r\n\r\n**Example Output:**\r\n`ag.code_changes('augur', period='year')`\r\n\r\n|         | commit_date           | count  |\r\n| ------------- |:-------------:| -----:|\r\n| 0      | 2017-01-01 00:00:00+00:00 |   1525 |\r\n| 1      | 2018-01-01 00:00:00+00:00  | 5140 |\r\n| 2 | 2019-01-01 00:00:00+00:00 |    711|\r\n\r\n`ag.code_changes('augur', period='month', begin_date='2018', end_date='2018-06')`\r\n\r\n|         | commit_date           | count  |\r\n| ------------- |:-------------:| -----:|\r\n|0 | 2018-01-01 00:00:00+00:00 |    99 |\r\n|1 | 2018-02-01 00:00:00+00:00 |    55 |\r\n|2 | 2018-03-01 00:00:00+00:00 |   105 |\r\n|3 | 2018-04-01 00:00:00+00:00 |   235 |\r\n|4 | 2018-05-01 00:00:00+00:00 |   506 |\r\n\r\n\r\nSigned-off-by: Parth Sharma <parth261297@gmail.com>	277109	1	2019-05-28 19:10:10	2019-05-28 19:10:10	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/284	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/284/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/284/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/284/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/pull/284	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjgyOTUxMzYx	449420858	22260291	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:13:13	284

336705	25430	277126	\N	\N	2019-03-28 17:07:14	Require DCO sign-off for new commits	This issue is to activate [protobot/dco](https://github.com/apps/dco) (or similar bot) to check that all commits have a sign-off in this repository. \r\n\r\nThe [CHAOSS Project Charter section 8.2.1](https://chaoss.community/about/charter/#user-content-8-intellectual-property-policy) requires that all contributions are signed-off. The CHAOSS project has been piloting the use of DCO sign-offs. Once contributors know how to do it, sign-offs are easy to do with little overhead. \r\n\r\n> For users of the git command line interface, a sign-off is accomplished with the `-s` as part of the commit command: `git commit -s -m 'This is a commit message'`\r\n>\r\n> For users of the GitHub interface, a sign-off is accomplished by writing `Signed-off-by: Your Name <YourName@example.org>` into the commit comment field. This can be automated by using a browser plugin like [scottrigby/dco-gh-ui](https://github.com/)\r\n\r\n**To-Do for repo maintainers:** Please inform your contributors about DCO sign-offs and comment on this issue when your are ready for the DCO bot to be activated on this repository.	277110	2	2019-04-26 18:42:10	2019-04-26 18:42:09	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/258	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/258/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/258/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/augur/issues/258/events	https://github.com/chaoss/augur/issues/258	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MjY2MDk2Mzg=	426609638	8862021	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:13:38	258

Read more about this file in (link to further information)\r\n* `setup.cfg` to configure some procedures. By now, just don't forget to uncomment those sections related to the data sources your listed in the projects.json (this shouldn't be needed if chaoss/grimoirelab-sirmordred#321 gets solved). Read more about this file in (link to further information)\r\n* `credentials.cfg` to list those tokens needed by some data sources. Read more about this file in (link to further information)\r\n\r\nOnce you are ready, there are several ways to start playing with GrimoireLab toolkit:\r\n\r\n## To play with GrimoireLab using pip packages\r\nRequirements: git, Elasticsearch, Kibiter (or Kibana), MariaDB, Redis, ...\r\n\r\nRun:\r\n```\r\n$ pip install grimoirelab\r\n```\r\nRun:\r\n```\r\n$ mordred -c setup.cfg credentials.cfg\r\n```\r\n\r\nLink to further reading about GrimoireLab python packages ...\r\n\r\n## To play with GrimoireLab using a single Docker image\r\n\r\nRequirements: git, Docker Engine\r\n\r\nRun:\r\n```\r\n$ docker run -p 127.0.0.1:9200:9200 -p 127.0.0.1:5601:5601 \\\r\n    -v $(pwd)/logs:/logs \\\r\n    -v $(pwd)/credentials.cfg:/override.cfg \\\r\n    -v $(pwd)/projects.json:/projects.json \\\r\n    -t grimoirelab/full\r\n```\r\n\r\nLink to further reading about GrimoireLab single Docker image ...\r\n\r\n## To play with GrimoireLab using Docker Compose\r\n\r\nRequirements: git, Docker Engine, Docker Compose\r\n\r\nModify settings files and run:\r\n```\r\n$ docker-compose up -d\r\n```\r\n\r\nLink to further reading about GrimoireLab using docker-compose ...\r\n	\N	0	2019-10-14 08:45:37	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/220	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/220/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/220/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/220/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/220	open	MDU6SXNzdWU1MDY1MTkxMDQ=	506519104	1178305	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:14:21	220

336753	25431	277126	\N	\N	2019-08-24 13:09:08	Evaluate adding feature for qualitative analysis by Social Currency method	At OSSNA19, [Samantha](https://www.linkedin.com/in/samanthavlogan/) introduced me to a method she is using for understanding the health of an online community, using Social Currency constructs. \r\n\r\nThe method is:\r\n1. Collect text (e.g., emails, comments, issues, pull requests, tweets, stack-overflow questions)\r\n2. Tag the text with topics (e.g., bug, feature request, question, complement)\r\n3. Tag the text with Social Currency constructs (i.e., Merit, Trust, Transparency, Utility, Consistency)\r\n4. Display in a pivot table the number of tags used across topics and SC constructs.\r\n\r\nThe tagging is at first a manual process and requires a good understanding of the community and good definition of the SC constructs. The training and implementation of the method in an organization is Samantha's business model.\r\n\r\nI am opening this issue, because I think GrimoireLab can support this method.\r\n1. Perceval already collects text from 30 different data sources.\r\n2. For the tagging, we may export the text into a spreadsheet, such as an [Airtable](https://airtable.com/) or Google Spreadsheet.\r\n3. The analysis can be made available in two places: 1) in the spreadsheet with a pivot table. 2) in Kibiter (GrimoireLab dashboard) together with other quantitative community health metrics.\r\n\r\nClosing condition:\r\n- A description of how the SC method can be supported and implemented in GrimoireLab\r\n- Requirements detailed enough for an engineer to begin building the solution\r\n- A time estimate for implementing the feature	277242	14	2019-09-11 09:38:47	2019-09-11 09:38:47	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/206	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/206/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/206/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/206/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/206	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0ODQ4MTU1NDI=	484815542	8862021	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:14:37	206

336776	25431	277245	\N	\N	2019-02-05 09:02:18	GSoC Idea: Implementing CHAOSS Metrics in Kibana Dashboards	[ This issue for addressing questions and comments related to [this GSoC idea](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-Ideas.md#idea-1-visualizing--chaoss-metrics-in-kibana-dashboards), which is one of the ideas proposed by the CHAOSS group for the 2019 edition of GSoC. CHAOSS is currently in the process of applying for GSoC slots, so we still don't know if this will be a part of GSoC'19. We will announce slots were granted (or not) as soon as we know. ]\r\n\r\n## Microtasks\r\n\r\nFor becoming familiar with the GrimoireLab technology, it is useful if you produce an analysis (Elasticsearch indexes and dashboard) for a GitHub project (git repos and GitHub issues and pull requests). Have a look at the "Before you start" chapter in the [GrimoireLab tutorial](https://grimoirelab.gitbooks.io/tutorial) to learn how to install the needed infrastructure (ElasticSearch, Kibiter, MariaDB) and GrimoireLab itself as Python packages, or how to deploy everything as a Docker container.\r\n\r\nOnce you're familiar with producing analysis, you can exploit the information in the indexes via Kibiter and Python scripts.\r\n\r\nThe aims of the project are as follows:\r\n\r\n  * Acquiring knowledge on GrimoireLab toolchain to generate enriched data from different data sources.\r\n  * Creating Kibana dashboards to obtain visual representations of different kind of metrics based on GrimoireLab data. Painless scripting language may be needed for particular tasks.\r\n  * Writing Python code to query GrimoireLab ElasticSearch databases and obtain from it new enriched data relevant for computing metrics defined by CHAOSS community. Possible technologies to achieve this aim include Python Pandas.\r\n\r\nThe aims will require working with ElasticSearch and Kibana, Python programming (could be needed to prepare the data for ElasticSearch indexes and Kibana visualizations), interaction with other people in the working group to learn about subtle details of the metrics, and producing documentation.\r\n\r\n  * __Difficulty:__ Medium\r\n  * __Requirements:__ Python programming. Interest in software analytics. Willingness to understand GrimoireLab internals and CHAOSS metrics.\r\n  * __Recommended:__ Experience with Python interfaces to databases would be convenient, but can be learned during the project. Experience in data analytics with Pandas, ElasticSearch, Kibana and Python Jupyter Notebooks will be a plus.\r\n  * __Mentors:__ Alberto Pérez García-Plaza (@alpgarcia) and Miguel Ángel Fernández (@mafesan).\r\n\r\n**NOTICE**: there is no need to do all the microtasks, you only need to show that your skills are in good standing for working in this project. We use these microtasks to evaluate candidates, so feel free to be creative adding things we are not explicitly requesting.\r\n\r\n**FOR ALL MICROTASKS**: whenever Python code is needed, it would be a plus if your code is integrated in the structure of the corresponding project. However this is not needed, so you can just write your own Python script that runs separately and produces the results you need to complete the microtask.\r\n\r\n**Microtask 1**: Based on [**Git enrichment** code](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-elk/blob/master/grimoire_elk/enriched/git.py) produce a new index or a [study](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-elk/blob/master/grimoire_elk/enriched/study_ceres_aoc.py) (whatever you feel is a better approach) including some new fields that may be interesting for future analysis. Some examples could be:\r\n * Country: based on timezone, add a string field containing a list of country names corresponding to a given time zone.\r\n * Directories: list of directories touched by a given commit.\r\n * File names: list of files touched by a given commit.\r\n * Number of authors: number of authors involved in a given commit.\r\n\r\n Build a Kibiter panel based on this new index and exploiting the new fields.\r\n\r\n**Microtask 2**: Given the **Git Areas of Code** index (generated by [study_ceres_aoc.py](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-elk/blob/master/grimoire_elk/enriched/study_ceres_aoc.py)) build a Kibiter dashboard to show a comparison between lines of code changed, directories and contributors. Resulting dashboard should show things like, for instance, what are the directories with more contributors and contributions. If you need more fields, feel free to propose an update to the study or even a new one.\r\n\r\n**Microtask 3**: Given the **Git** index (generated by [git.py](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-elk/blob/master/grimoire_elk/enriched/git.py)) build a Kibiter dashboard to show at least one following factors (see [definitions](https://github.com/chaoss/metrics)):\r\n* Bus Factor / Pony factor\r\n* Elephant factor\r\n\r\nTo be able to build this dashboard, a new index is needed, including pre-computed values for all the factors splitted by projects and quarters. It would be also needed to pre-compute the factors for all aggregated data. The dashboard should include the following visualizations (per factor):\r\n* Evolution per quarter (e.g., `Bar Chart` visualization).\r\n* Table showing the data aggregated by project.\r\n\r\nBonus: Implementing all the factors (even other not included here) the dashboard could include a `Radar` visualization including those factors (with normalized values).\r\n\r\n**Microtask 4**: Given the **Git Areas of Code** index ([study_ceres_aoc.py](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-elk/blob/master/grimoire_elk/enriched/study_ceres_aoc.py)) build a Kibiter dashboard to measure developer's work load. How this metric is computed is up to you, but here you have a couple of ideas:\r\n* Use the number of lines of coded changed per user\r\n* Use the number of modified files\r\n\r\nOpen question: Should documentation and code be considered separately? Please include your consideration in the documentation included in your repo (see **Showing the work you did** section).\r\n\r\n\r\n### If you want, you can also:\r\n\r\n**Microtask 5**: Produce a pull request for any of the GrimoireLab tools, and try to follow instructions until it gets accepted. Try do do something simple that you consider useful, not necessarily fix to the code: improvement of comments, documentation or testing will usually be easier to get accepted, and very useful for the project. Have a look at the open issues and try to solve one of them. Please, avoid just producing a random pull request just to have another microtask: the objective is not that you get one more microtask done, but that you understand how to interact with developers in the project contributing with something that could be useful).\r\n\r\n\r\n## Showing the work you did\r\n\r\nIf you want to show the work you did, open a GitHub repository, and upload to it:\r\n\r\n* A `README.md` file explaining what you did, and linking to the results (which will be in the same repository, see below). This will be the main file to show your skills and interest on the project, so try to make it organized and clear, in a way that we can easily understand what you did.\r\n\r\n* Screenshots of the dashboard(s) you produced, and any other information needed to import them into Kibiter and get them working (configuration files for running the tools needed for building the indexes, etc.). Please **remember removing passwords and/or auth tokens that could be in them before uploading**. In the REAME.md file, link all those files, telling about which GitHub projects you analyzed.\r\n\r\n* Python scripts you produced, with enough information (in comments and/or in the README.md file) so that we can run them if needed.
