336777	25431	277242	\N	\N	2019-02-02 09:17:41	GSoC Idea: Support of Source Code Related Metrics	[ This issue for addressing questions and comments related to this GSoC idea, which is one of the [ideas proposed by the CHAOSS group for the 2019 edition of GSoC](https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/organizations/6021327920562176/).]\r\n\r\n## Description\r\n\r\nCurrently, GrimoireLab allows to produce analytics with data extracted from more than 30 tools related with contributing to Open Source development such as version control systems, issue trackers and forums. Despite the large set of metrics available in GrimoireLab, none of them relies on information extracted from source code, thus limiting the end-users to benefit of a wider spectrum of software development data.\r\n\r\n[Graal](https://github.com/Bitergia/graal) is a tool that allows to conduct customizable and incremental analysis of source code by leveraging on existing tools, and produce an output that conforms to the data that can be processed by GrimoireLab. Graal already offers analysis about code complexity, quality, dependencies, security and licensing, however currently it is not integrated with GrimoireLab.\r\n\r\nThis idea is about adding support to GrimoireLab to produce source code related metrics using Graal.\r\n\r\nThe aims of the project are as follows:\r\n  * Understanding the GrimoireLab components (Perceval, ELK, Mordred and Sigils) and the corresponding tool-chain.\r\n  * Adapting ELK and Mordred to be able to execute Graal and process the data produced.\r\n  * Producing analytics with Graal data and including them in Sigils.\r\n  * Evaluating the implementation with projects of different sizes.\r\n\r\nOther aims, such as enhancing Graal to support more analysis or improve existing ones are completely within scope.\r\n\r\nThe aims will require extending GrimoireLab functionality to integrate Graal.\r\n\r\n  * _Difficulty:_ medium\r\n  * _Requirements:_ Python programming. Interest in software analytics. Willingness to understand GrimoireLab internals.\r\n  * _Recommended:_ Experience with ElasticSearch and Kibana would be convenient, but can be learned during the project.\r\n  * _Mentors:_ @jgbarah , @valeriocos \r\n\r\n## Microtasks\r\n\r\nFor becoming familiar with GrimoireLab, you can start by reading some documentation. You can find useful information at:\r\n- [GrimoireLab Tutorial](https://chaoss.github.io/grimoirelab-tutorial/)\r\n- [Perceval: Software Project Data at Your Will](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/325334393_Perceval_Software_Project_Data_at_Your_Will)\r\n- [Graal: The Quest for Source Code Knowledge](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/326942711_Graal_The_Quest_for_Source_Code_Knowledge)\r\n- The GitHub repositories hosting the tools (https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval, https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-sirmordred, https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-*, and https://github.com/Bitergia/graal)\r\n\r\nOnce you're familiar with Grimoirelab, you can have a look at the following microtasks.\r\n\r\n- Microtask 0:\r\nDownload [PyCharm](https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/) and get familiar with it (for instance, you can follow [this tutorial](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/pycharm/meet-pycharm.html)).\r\n\r\n- Microtask 1:\r\nSet up Perceval to be executed from PyCharm.\r\n\r\n- Microtask 2:\r\nCreate a Python script to execute Perceval via its Python interface using the Git and GitHub backends. Feel free to select any target repository, for instance the [GitHub repository](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval) hosting Perceval.\r\n\r\n- Microtask 3:\r\nBased on the JSON documents produced by Perceval and its source code, try to answer the following questions:\r\n  - What is the meaning of the JSON attribute 'timestamp'?\r\n  - What is the meaning of the JSON attribute 'updated_on'? \r\n  - What is the meaning of the JSON attribute 'origin'? \r\n  - What is the meaning of the JSON attribute 'category'?\r\n  - What is the meaning of the JSON attribute 'uuid'?\r\n  - Which are the common methods of the Perceval backends?\r\n  - List and explain at least 3 Git commands used by the Perceval backend (you can rely on the [Git documentation](https://git-scm.com/docs))\r\n\r\n- Microtask 4:\r\nCreate a Python script to fetch data from [SoftwareHeritage](https://archive.softwareheritage.org/) using its [API](https://archive.softwareheritage.org/api/). \r\nGiven a target GitHub repository, the script should return a message if the repository is not available on SoftwareHeritage or the date of the last visit.\r\nThe script should rely on the endpoints: [origin](https://archive.softwareheritage.org/api/1/origin/) and [visits](https://archive.softwareheritage.org/api/1/origin/visits/).\r\nPlease use the Python library [requests](http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/) to issue requests to the SofwareHeritage API.\r\n\r\n- Microtask 5:\r\nSet up Graal to be executed from PyCharm. \r\n\r\n- Microtask 6:\r\nCreate a Python script to execute Graal via its Python interface using the CoCom and CoLic backends. Feel free to select any target repository, for instance the [GitHub repository](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-toolkit) hosting Toolkit.\r\n\r\n- Microtask 7:\r\nBased on the JSON documents produced by Graal and its source code, try to answer the following questions:\r\n  - Which are the common methods of the Graal backends?\r\n  - List and explain at least 2 Git commands used by Graal (and not implemented in Perceval).\r\n\r\n- Microtask 8:\r\nCreate a Python script to execute [flake8](https://pypi.org/project/flake8/) for a given commit of any Git repository. Given a commit SHA and a Git repository, the script should clone the repository (if it doesn't exist locally), perform a checkout based on the commit SHA and execute flake8 on that checkout. The script should return a message that either lists the errors found or "OK" if flake8 successfully ended.\r\n\r\n- Microtask 9:\r\nSubmit at least a PR to one of the GrimoireLab repositories to fix an issue, improve the documentation, etc.\r\n\r\n## Showing the work you did\r\nIf you want to show the work you did, open a GitHub repository, and upload to it:\r\n\r\nA README.md file explaining what you did, and linking to the results (which will be in the same repository, see below). This will be the main file to show your skills and interest on the project, so try to make it organized and clear, in a way that we can easily understand what you did.\r\n\r\n## Submitting information for the application process\r\n\r\nYou must complete microtask 0, and at least 6 microtasks, in the case you're interested in this idea.\r\n\r\nOnce you completed at least one microtask, go to the governance repository and create a pull request to add yourself, your information, and a link to your repository with the completed micro-task(s) in the [GSoC-interest.md file](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-interest.md).\r\n\r\nYou are welcome to include in your repository other information that could be of interest, such as open issues or pull requests submitted to the project to which you intend to contribute during GSoC, contributions to other projects, skills, and other related information.\r\n\r\nYou must complete these things by GSoC deadline for proposals. Make sure to also submit the information required by GSoC for applicants (i.e., project proposal), linking to it from your pull request in the [GSoC-interest.md file](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-interest.md).\r\n\r\n## Getting feedback for your proposal & microtasks\r\n\r\nOur idea is to have a look at proposals that are registered in the governance repository starting after 25th March, when students can formally apply. But if you have specific doubts, comments, or whatever, use this issue.\r\n\r\nIn general, we don't want to give advice too specific to one case, because that could give some advantage to some person with respect to the others. Answering questions and addressing comments (if you want, based on your proposal) is not a problem as long as that's done in public, hence the threads in this issue.\r\n\r\n## Asking for help\r\nIf you need help, please use the following channels:\r\n- Comments in this issue\r\n- #grimoirelab channel in Freenode IRC	277242	38	2019-09-11 09:33:39	2019-09-11 09:33:39	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/182	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/182/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/182/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/182/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/182	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MDU5NjU3NjI=	405965762	6515067	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:15:15	182

Gonzalez-Barahona <jgb@gsyc.es>	277192	0	2019-03-29 09:12:24	2019-03-29 09:12:24	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/189	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/189/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/189/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/189/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/pull/189	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjY1NDMwNjg5	426616929	1039693	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:15:00	189
336771	25431	277126	\N	\N	2019-03-28 17:11:00	Require DCO sign-off for new commits	This issue is to activate [protobot/dco](https://github.com/apps/dco) (or similar bot) to check that all commits have a sign-off in this repository. \r\n\r\nThe [CHAOSS Project Charter section 8.2.1](https://chaoss.community/about/charter/#user-content-8-intellectual-property-policy) requires that all contributions are signed-off. The CHAOSS project has been piloting the use of DCO sign-offs. Once contributors know how to do it, sign-offs are easy to do with little overhead. \r\n\r\n> For users of the git command line interface, a sign-off is accomplished with the `-s` as part of the commit command: `git commit -s -m 'This is a commit message'`\r\n>\r\n> For users of the GitHub interface, a sign-off is accomplished by writing `Signed-off-by: Your Name <YourName@example.org>` into the commit comment field. This can be automated by using a browser plugin like [scottrigby/dco-gh-ui](https://github.com/)\r\n\r\n**To-Do for repo maintainers:** Please inform your contributors about DCO sign-offs and comment on this issue when your are ready for the DCO bot to be activated on this repository.	277126	5	2019-04-16 13:27:35	2019-04-16 13:27:35	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/188	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/188/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/188/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/188/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/188	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MjY2MTEzNjc=	426611367	8862021	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:15:01	188

We have to add more memory to the Java machine, as it says in this post:\r\n\r\n- https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/heap-size.html\r\n\r\nI solved the error adding in the Dockerfile of grimoirelab-full this line (before the elasticsearch installation):\r\n\r\n```\r\nENV ES_JAVA_OPTS "-Xms2g -Xmx2g"\r\n```\r\nNow, the enrichment of git works well:\r\n\r\n```\r\nEnrichment for git: starting...\r\nCollection for pipermail: starting...\r\nEnrichment for git: finished after 00:00:50 hours\r\n```	277192	2	2019-04-01 09:52:11	2019-04-01 09:52:10	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/187	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/187/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/187/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/187/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/187	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MjQ5NTU5MDQ=	424955904	9249232	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:15:03	187
336773	25431	277253	\N	\N	2019-02-27 08:31:45	[metric] How long does it take to answer an email in the mailing list?	The goal of this task is to have calculated the time to first response in the mailing lists data source.\r\n\r\nAs done in other data sources such as Discourse or Issues in GitHub, this number helps to understand the time to attention. However the internal hierarchy of emails and how they have to be calculated makes this analysis a bit more complex than the others.\r\n\r\nA potential solution for this would to look for those emails that are starting threads (so they do not have any reply-to mbox header) and take one of them. Then list all of the emails that are referring to this in the reply-to mbox header and take the oldest one. 336793	25431	277237	\N	\N	2018-11-19 04:16:33	Sorting Hat 1.0	Sorting Hat was started as a command line tool into the Metrics Grimoire project. Its purpose was to make easier the daily tasks related with identities management.\r\n\r\nLate,  it was adopted as part of GrimoireLab project. It was been used as a command line tool but also as a library by Grimoire ELK library to access identities data. Despite this usage, Sorting Hat was not conceived for the simultaneous access of multiple actors to its data, This causes many problems and and produces complex workflows to operate it.\r\n\r\nSorting Hat will be converted into a web service to solve these problems. \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n	\N	2	2018-11-19 20:06:14	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/165	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/165/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/165/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/165/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/165	open	MDU6SXNzdWUzODIwNTEwMzE=	382051031	833352	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:15:38	165
336794	25431	277237	\N	\N	2018-11-19 03:34:59	Definition of basic Git data model	The goal of this task is to define a model of data for Git data source. This basic model will comprise those entities that not require a context to be generated.\r\n\r\nThe model defined by CVSAnalY to store Git data can be used as a starting point. This model defined some entities such as:\r\n\r\n* Commit\r\n* Action\r\n* File\r\n* Repository\r\n* Tag\r\n* People\r\n\r\nA diagram of the model can be found [here](https://github.com/MetricsGrimoire/CVSAnalY/blob/master/db/cvsanaly_model.svg).\r\n 	\N	0	2018-11-19 03:34:59	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/164	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/164/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/164/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/164/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/164	open	MDU6SXNzdWUzODIwNDQ2ODk=	382044689	833352	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:15:39	164
336795	25431	277237	\N	\N	2018-11-19 03:23:44	Data model	The purpose of this task is to define the basic data model we will use in GrimoireLab. This means, to determine what entities can be extracted from the different data sources we analyze. Plus, how these entities are related.\r\n\r\nThe model should be composed by two levels of data (maybe more) and will establish how entities are linked or related to each other. In a graph, entities are the nodes and relationships are the edges between these nodes. We can define three different types of entities:\r\n\r\n* Entities without context: directly extracted from raw items (i.e commit, commit actions, issue, issue comments)\r\n* Entities generated with context: merged entities or extracted with complex logic (i.e demography, onion model)\r\n* Relationships: links between entities (ie. which commits fix which issues, author of an issue)\r\n\r\nWe well start defining the model of those entities without context, progressing to more complex relationships.\r\n\r\n**Related tasks**\r\n\r\n- [ ] Git data model (#164) 	\N	0	2018-11-19 03:37:04	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/163	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/163/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/163/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/163/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/163	open	MDU6SXNzdWUzODIwNDI4NTA=	382042850	833352	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:15:39	163

336807	25431	277245	\N	\N	2018-09-26 11:01:45	Provide different access level to Hatstall	It would be nice to have at least two access levels to Hatstall.\r\n\r\n**Problem**: each user should be able to modify their affiliations. To avoid problems, each user should not be able to modify other affiliations. But there is no way of knowing what affiliations corresponds to a given user/profile, so there is no way to restrict their permissions.\r\n\r\nTo solve this, there could be two access levels:\r\n* admin:  this profile is allowed to modify data with no restrictions.\r\n* user: this profile allows to modify data, but instead of persisting changes, those changes are recorded as `actions`. Those `actions` need to be approved later by an admin level user.\r\n\r\nThis way any user could fix their data through a review process.	\N	0	2018-09-26 11:01:45	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/151	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/151/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/151/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/151/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/151	open	MDU6SXNzdWUzNjM5NzI1MTc=	363972517	3502941	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:15:50	151

336822	25431	277192	336822	336822	2018-08-06 07:58:56	Prepare some machinery for including grimoirelab itself in the release	    Prepare some machinery for including grimoirelab itself in the release\r\n    \r\n    Now, GrimoireLab is a Python package, so that it can be included\r\n    in the GrimoireLab release. This package will include as dependenncies\r\n    the versions of all other GrimoireLab packages in the release.\r\n    The package is built from the grimoirelab directory.\r\n    \r\n    We have a new option in build_grimoirelab to compute the dependencies:\r\n    --dependencies, along with another one, --depfile to specify the\r\n    file to write them. This allows to compute the specific dependencies\r\n    for a certain GrimoireLab release, so that the grimoirelab package\r\n    depends on them. This way, installing a certain grimoirelab package\r\n    always pulls the GrimoireLab release packages.\r\n    \r\n    This commit also includes a requirements.txt file, built for the latest official\r\n    release. This should be a part of the commit changing the release file,\r\n    but since this is the first time...\r\n    \r\n    A new file BUILDING.md is also included, with detailed instructions\r\n    about how to build a release.\r\n\r\n    The options for testing in build_grimoirelab now can also use a configuration\r\n    directory for the tests. A sample of it is included as docker/testconf.\r\n    \r\n    Some files are changed to adapt to these new functionalities: ansible_release.yml.\r\n    \r\n    The configuration files for analyzing CHAOSS, which are used to produce the\r\n    demo dashboard by the grimoirelab/full Docker image, have been updated\r\n    (identities.yaml, menu.yaml, mordred-*.cfg, projects.json...) Now, the latest\r\n    studies (onion, areas of code, etc.) are also produced for that dashboard.\r\n	277192	0	2018-08-23 10:09:05	2018-08-23 10:09:05	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/136	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/136/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/136/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/136/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/pull/136	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjA2MzE3NzIw	347817942	1039693	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:16:04	136
336823	25431	277192	\N	\N	2018-07-22 19:21:48	Organizing documentation	This issue was triggered by the insightful comments by @filmaj in chaoss/grimoirelab-sirmordred#167\r\n\r\nTo summarize, now we have the following documentation:\r\n\r\n* Some README.md files in source code repos, including some in subdirectories of them.\r\n* Some automatically built documentation from source code comments. In some cases (well, in one case) it is available in readthedocs: [Perceval documentation](http://perceval.readthedocs.io/)\r\n* The [Grimoirelab Tutorial](https://chaoss.github.io/grimoirelab-tutorial/), produced automatically from md files in docs dir in this repo.\r\n* Some interesting information here and there in some issues.\r\n\r\nI agree with @filmaj that we should better organize it. In principle, the idea (I think)  was:\r\n\r\n* README files for stuff like how to configure and run, how to contribute (maybe in separate CONTRIBUTING files), how to run tests and do other development-related stuff, and links to further documentation. In short, this would be information mainly for developers, and for letting users know the very basics, and where to find more. I would say this would be a kind of a reference manual for users, and in part (except for everything in the next item) for developers.\r\n* Automatically generated documentation from comments in the source code. This should be for the rest of developer-related information, including definition of the APIs, for example.\r\n* Tutorial. This was intended not as a reference manual, but as a tutorial of how to get stuff done. This should be the second thing a user would consult, after the README files that would explain the very basics, and after the detailed user guides that would be also a part of those README.\r\n\r\nWhat do you (anyone reading this issue) think about this organization? Is still a sensible schema? 336853	25431	277192	336853	336853	2017-10-08 23:06:40	Script to produce Python packages for a coordinated release	I've written a little script to help in the process of creating the Python packages for a coordinated release. In its current form, it can produce all packages for the repos that already support Python packages, and install them in a virtual environment where they could be tested.\r\n\r\nTo avoid problems with the Python installation in the host where the packages are produced, a virtual environment with installed dependencies for building is produced, and packages are built in it.\r\n\r\nThe script accepts options to build or install, to select only a certain set of modules, to define directories for building and installing virtual environments, for the temporary repositories, for where to produce the Python packages, and to select a coordinated release file.	277236	1	2017-10-10 03:59:50	2017-10-10 03:59:50	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/5	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/5/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/5/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/5/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/pull/5	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTQ1MzU4MDk1	263760013	1039693	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:16:36	5

336858	25431	277192	336858	336858	2018-06-24 16:24:04	[build_grimoirelab] Improve support for testing	This patch improves support for testing GrimoireLab pip packages. Now, it allows to run `setup.py test` for each module, including configuration files for testing (eg, when they are needed to express addresses or credentials to access services). One of the commits also removes the need to build before testing, allowing that way to test already built packages (in fact, they will be used as dependencies, since unit tests will always be run on the source code).\r\n\r\nNow, all build packages for a GrimoireLab distro can be tested by running (assuming built packages are in `dist`, configuration files for testing are in `testconf`, which will have one subdirectory per module with testing config files, with the same path they should be copied to the source code repo befor running tests, and `release` is the release file to test) :\r\n\r\n```\r\n$ python --test --distdir dist --fail --confdir testconf --relfile release \r\n```	277236	0	2018-06-29 19:13:47	2018-06-25 05:58:38	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/124	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/124/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/124/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/124/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/pull/124	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTk2OTU3Njk5	335192237	1039693	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:16:41	124

336866	25431	277238	\N	\N	2018-06-04 08:11:47	No way to create an index pattern with ES 6.1.0 and Kibiter 6.1.0	I am testing latest GrimoireLab pip packages and this simple `docker-compose.yml`file:\r\n```\r\nelasticsearch:\r\n  image: bitergia/elasticsearch:6.1.0\r\n  command: /elasticsearch/bin/elasticsearch -E network.bind_host=0.0.0.0\r\n  ports:\r\n    - "9200:9200"\r\n  environment:\r\n    - ES_JAVA_OPTS=-Xms3g -Xmx3g\r\n\r\nkibiter:\r\n  image: bitergia/kibiter:6.1.0-newmenu\r\n  links:\r\n    - elasticsearch\r\n  ports:\r\n   - "5601:5601"\r\n  environment:\r\n    - PROJECT_NAME=jsmanrique\r\n    - NODE_OPTIONS=--max-old-space-size=1200\r\n    - ELASTICSEARCH_URL=http://elasticsearch:9200\r\n\r\nmariadb:\r\n  restart: on-failure:5\r\n  image: mariadb:10.0\r\n  ports:\r\n    - "127.0.0.1:3306:3306"\r\n  environment:\r\n    - MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD= *******************************************\r\n    - MYSQL_ALLOW_EMPTY_PASSWORD=********************************\r\n  command: --wait_timeout=2592000 --interactive_timeout=2592000 --max_connections=300\r\n  log_driver: "json-file"\r\n  log_opt:\r\n    max-size: "100m"\r\n    max-file: "3"\r\n```\r\n\r\nSadly, each time I run a `mordred.cfg` file, I get a Kibiter without an index pattern configured and I am not able to set up one through Kibiter interface. The cause seems to be a wrong `.kibana` index has been created first.\r\n\r\nThe only way to achieve a running dashboard has been to remove existing `.kibana`\r\n```\r\n$ curl -X DELETE 'http://localhost:9200/.kibana'\r\n```\r\n\r\nNow, I can set up an index pattern and play with the data.\r\n\r\nAs collateral damage of removing the `.kibana` index, the Kibiter dashboards navigation menu is lost!\r\n\r\nWouldn't it be nice that `mordred` takes care of setting up a default index pattern or something similar to @jgbarah  solution in its [Dockerfile](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/blob/master/docker/Dockerfile-full):\r\n```\r\ncurl -XPOST "http://127.0.0.1:5601/api/kibana/settings/indexPattern:placeholder" \\\r\n          -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'kbn-version: '${KB_VERSION} \\\r\n          -H 'Accept: application/json' -d '{"value": "*"}' \\\r\n--silent --output /dev/null ; \\\r\n```	\N	3	2018-06-04 08:26:43	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/116	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/116/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/116/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/116/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/116	open	MDU6SXNzdWUzMjg5NTA3Nzg=	328950778	1178305	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:16:47	116

336879	25431	277192	336879	336879	2018-04-18 23:14:19	[build_grimoirelab] Add check that tools can be run	This is a first try at improving the testing when producing packages for Pypi. Two new checks have been included:\r\n\r\n* That each module can be installed alone (with its dependencies)\r\nin a virtual environment.\r\n* That one executable can be run for each package. Usually,\r\nfor each package, the main executable is run with the "--help"\r\nargument.\r\n\r\nThe structure of the script is now more complete, paving the way for running the unit tests of each module.\r\n\r\nRunning build_grimoirelab as follows, uncovered three cases of packages that, when installed alone with their dependencies, cannot be run:\r\n\r\n```\r\n./build_grimoirelab --check --distdir /tmp/dist --reposdir /tmp/repos --relfile ../releases/18.04-02 --fail\r\n...\r\nFailed check run (grimoire-elk)\r\nFailed check run (kidash)\r\nFailed check run (grimoire-mordred)\r\n```\r\n\r\nI'm opening pull requests for these projects, fixing the problems.	277236	0	2018-04-19 05:39:13	2018-04-19 05:39:13	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/103	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/103/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/103/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/103/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/pull/103	closed	MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTgyNjI3MzI5	315674034	1039693	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:16:59	103

336895	25431	277289	\N	\N	2018-03-14 16:50:33	Ignore submodule updates when calculating git stats	Gerrit has a feature called Submodule subscriptions [0] where it will automatically move the commit hash pointer for aggregator projects that are configured to subscribe to a submodule. When it does this however it automatically creates a new commit in the aggregator project for the updated submodule.\r\n\r\nYou can see many examples in this project [1] where most of the commits are just "Update git submodules" the result of this is that the contribution of to submodule project causes contributions to count more than once (by the number of projects that load the submodule).\r\n\r\n[0] https://gerrit-review.googlesource.com/Documentation/user-submodules.html\r\n[1] https://github.com/opendaylight/releng-autorelease/commits/master	\N	5	2018-03-20 17:35:37	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/87	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/87/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/87/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/87/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/87	open	MDU6SXNzdWUzMDUyNDI4NDU=	305242845	150177	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:17:14	87

336899	25431	277238	\N	\N	2018-03-13 01:51:28	Support for projects hierarchy	Wouldn't it be nice having some kind of projects hierarchy in GrimoireLab?\r\n\r\nCurrently GrimoireLab only supports 1 level hierarchy according to [projects.json example](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-mordred/blob/master/docker/example_conf/projects.json) and [the existing documentation](https://grimoirelab.gitbooks.io/tutorial/content/mordred/the-projects-file.html). So we have `Project > Repositories`\r\n\r\nIn [Bestiary](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-bestiary) is being introduced the Ecosystem level, so 2 levels are gonna be supported (sort of): `Ecosytem > Project > Repositories`\r\n\r\nIs it gonna support `Ecosystem > Project > ... > Project > Repositories`? Do we need that deepth? This might be also related with #71\r\n\r\nI would like also knowing if the community would agree on the following assumptions:\r\n* Do we expect that some same repositories might be in different projects or ecosystems? I would say "no, by design".\r\n* Might some projects be under no specific ecosystem? I would say "no, by design".\r\n* Might some repositories be under no specific project? I would say "no, by design".\r\n* Project names might be not unique. For example, several ecosystems might have a "Documentation" project. 336912	25431	277192	\N	\N	2018-02-16 19:54:59	GSoC idea: Reporting of CHAOSS Metrics	[ This issue for addressing questions and comments related to this GSoC idea, which is one of [the ideas proposed by the CHAOSS group](https://wiki.linuxfoundation.org/chaoss/gsoc-ideas) for the 2018 edition of GSoC ]\r\n\r\n[Edited, 2018-03-03: Added procedure for uploading information for application.]\r\n[Edited, 2018-03-12: Added link to guidelines for proposals]\r\n\r\nCurrently, GrimoireLab includes a tool for reporting: [Manuscripts](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-manuscripts). This tool reads data from a GrimoireLab ElasticSearch database, and produces with it a PDF report with relevant metrics for a set of analyzed projects. Internally, Manuscripts uses some Python code to produce charts and CSV tables, which are integrated into a LaTeX document to produce the final PDF. Other approaches, such as producing Jupyter notebooks, will be explored too.\r\n\r\nThis idea is about adding support to Manuscripts to produce reports based on the work of the CHAOSS Community. Since Manuscripts is still a moving target, this will be also a chance to participate in the general development of the tool itself, to convert it into a generic reporting system for GrimoireLab data.\r\n\r\nThe aims of the project are as follows:\r\n\r\n* Writing Python code to query GrimoireLab Elastisearch databases and obtain from it the metrics relevant for the report. Possible technologies to achieve this aim include Python Pandas.\r\n* Writing Python code to produce suitable representation for those metrics, such as tables and charts.\r\n* Adapting current tools to produce reports directly from data sources, by managing the GrimoireLab toolchain. Possible solutions include adding the code to Mordred, the tool orchestrating GrimoireLab tools.\r\n\r\nOther aims, such as producing Jupyter notebooks as a final result or an intermediate step are completely within scope.\r\n\r\n* Difficulty: easy/medium\r\n* Requirements: Python programming. Interest in software analytics. Willingness to understand GrimoireLab internals.\r\n* Recommended: Experience with Python interfaces to databases would be convenient, but can be learned during the project. Experience with Latex and/or Python Jupyter Notebooks would help.\r\n* Mentors: @jgbarah , @germonprez , @jcabot\r\n\r\n## Microtasks\r\n\r\nFor becoming familiar with the GitLab technology, it is useful if you produce an analysis (Elasticsearch indexes and dashboard) for a GitHub project (git repos and GitHub issues and pull requests). Have a look at the "Before you start" chapter in the [GrimoireLab tutorial](https://grimoirelab.gitbooks.io/tutorial) to learn how to install the needed infrastructure (ElasticSearch, Kibiter, MariaDB) and GrimoireLab itself as Python packages, or how to deploy everything as a Docker container.\r\n\r\nOnce you're familiar with producing analysis, you can exploit the information in the indexes via a Python script, preferably presented as a Python [Jupyter Notebook](http://jupyter.org/):\r\n\r\n* Microtask 1: Produce a listing of the number of new committers per month, and the number of commits for each of them, as a table and as a CSV file. Use the GrimoireLab enriched index for git.\r\n\r\n* Microtask 2: Produce a chart showing the distribution of time-to-close (using the corresponding field in the GrimoireLab enriched index for GitHub issues) for issues already closed, and opened during the last six months.\r\n\r\n* Microtask 3: Produce a listing of repositories, as a table and as CSV file, with the number of commits authored, issues opened, and pull requests opened, during the last three months, ordered by the total number (commits plus issues plus pull requests).\r\n\r\n* Microtask 4: Perform any other analysis you may find interesting, based on GrimoireLab enriched indexes for git and GitHub repositories.\r\n\r\nIf you want, you can also:\r\n\r\n* Microtask 5: Produce a pull request for any of the GrimoireLab tools, and try to follow instructions until it gets accepted. Try do do something simple that you consider useful, not necessarily fix to the code: improvement of comments, documentation or testing will usually be easier to get accepted, and very useful for the project. Please, avoid just producing a random pull request just to have another microtask: the objective is not that you get one more microtask done, but that you understand how to interact with developers in the project contributing with something that could be useful).\r\n\r\nOf course, there is no need to do all the microtasks, you only need to show that your skills are in good standing for working in this project.\r\n\r\n## Showing the work you did\r\n\r\nIf you want to show the work you did, open a GitHub repository, and upload to it:\r\n\r\n* A `README.md` file explaining what you did, and linking to the results (which will be in the same repository, see below). This will be the main file to show your skills and interest on the project, so try to make it organized and clear, in a way that we can easily understand what you did.\r\n\r\n* Screenshots of the dashboard(s) you produced, and configuration files you used for them (if any). Please remember removing passwords and/or auth tokens that could be in them, before uploading. In the `REAME.md` file, link all those files, telling about which GitHub projects you analyzed.\r\n\r\n* Python scripts and/or Python Jupyter notebooks you produced, with enough information (in comments and/or in the `README.md` file) so that we can run them if needed. Upload Python scripts ready to work assuming GrimoireLab packages are already installed. Upload Jupyter notebooks ready to be seen via the GitHub web interface.\r\n\r\n* Links to the pull request you did (if any), along with any comment you may have about it.\r\n\r\n## Submitting information for the application process\r\n\r\n* You must complete at least one micro-task related to the idea you are interested on.\r\n\r\n* Once you completed at least one micro-task, go to the governance repository and create a pull request to add yourself, your information, and a link to your repository with the completed micro-task(s) in the [GSoC-interest.md file](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-interest.md) (see above for the contents of the repository).\r\n\r\n* You are welcome to include in your repository other information that could be of interest, such as open issues or pull requests submitted to the project to which you intend to contribute during GSoC, contributions to other projects, skills, and other related information.\r\n\r\n* You must complete these things by March 27 16:00 UTC. Make sure to also submit the information required by GSoC for applicants (i.e., project proposal), linking to it from your pull request in the [GSoC-interest.md file](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-interest.md).\r\n\r\n* [Message to the mailing list with guidelines on proposals](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/oss-health-metrics/2018-March/000532.html).\r\n\r\n## Useful documentation\r\n\r\n* [GrimoireLab Tutorial](https://grimoirelab.gitbooks.io/tutorial)\r\n\r\n* [CHAOSS Metrics](https://wiki.linuxfoundation.org/chaoss/metrics#chaoss-oss-project-metrics) (work in progress)\r\n\r\n* [Elasticsearch Python module](https://elasticsearch-py.readthedocs.io): for accessing Elasticsearch from Python, using its REST interface.\r\n\r\n* [Elasticsearch DSL Python module](https://elasticsearch-dsl.readthedocs.io): for accessing Elasticsearch from Python, higher lever (more Pythonic) module.\r\n\r\n## Asking for help\r\n\r\nIf you need help, please use the 336911	25431	277192	\N	\N	2018-02-16 19:59:10	GSoC idea: Support of Standard Formats for Description of Projects	[ This issue for addressing questions and comments related to this GSoC idea, which is one of [the ideas proposed by the CHAOSS group](https://wiki.linuxfoundation.org/chaoss/gsoc-ideas) for the 2018 edition of GSoC ]\r\n\r\n[Edited, 2018-02-28: Added some more detail to the idea, and changed its structure so that it is easier to understand.]\r\n[Edited, 2018-03-03: Added procedure for uploading information for application.]\r\n[Edited, 2018-03-12: Added link to guidelines for proposals]\r\n\r\nCurrently, GrimoireLab uses its own format for describing a project, including the data sources (repositories to retrieve information from), the internal organization of the project (e.g., in subprojects), and specifics about how the data is to be presented. It also uses its own format for expressing the many identities that a person may have in the different data sources, and the information related to their profile (preferred name, affiliation, etc.). The usual workflow includes people maintaining GrimoireLab dashboards to edit those files to decide which repositories are analyzed, or to add new identities that should be considered for certain persons. However, there are sources of information that could be retrieved automatically for at least some of that information. This idea is about walking that way of retrieving information automatically, using files maintained by the projects, or APIs provided by services.\r\n\r\nSome of these sources of information are:\r\n\r\n* For the project structure, including repositories, some standard formats already exist, that can be directly used, or used with some modifications. Among them, [DOAP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOAP) is one of the most interesting ones, but there are many others. DOAP is used, for example, to define all Apache projects.\r\n\r\n* Some projects, such as Eclipse or OpenStack, maintain their own format for expressing their structure, including their repositories.\r\n\r\n* Some APIs offer list of repositories for projects, such as GitHub, BitBucket or GitLab, which provide lists of repositories for a given organization, or Gerrit, which provides lists of git repositories.\r\n\r\n* Some projects maintain identities of developers in some files in git repositories. Some popular formats include gitdm (used by the tool of the same name) and mailmap (used by git and other tools), that allow to declare several email addresses to be merged for the same person, and in some cases affiliation and other information.\r\n\r\n* Some projects use consistent naming in all or most of the datasources, allowing for easy identification of the same person in all of them.\r\n\r\nThis idea is about identifying formats used by projects to describe themselves and adding support to GrimoireLab. This includes not only static formats, but also APIs.\r\n\r\nThe aims of the project are as follows:\r\n\r\n* Supporting as many as possible of the formats and APIs mentioned above, and other that could found interesting, by either converting them to the current GrimoireLab format, or more likely, directly supporting it in Mordred or some related tools. For some of them, there is already partial support (for example, gitdm is partially supported by SortingHat, or the OpenStack format is partially supported by Mordred).\r\n\r\n* Testing the implementation with large projects supporting those formats, such as Apache Server (that uses DOAP), or some GitHub organization, etc.\r\n\r\nThe aims may require modifications to Mordred and other related tools to make them modular and simplify the implementation of support for future formats or APIs.\r\n\r\n* Difficulty: easy/medium\r\n* Requirements: Python programming. Willingness to understand GrimoireLab internals.\r\n* Recommended: Experience with Python HTTP and XML libraries would be convenient, but can be learned during the project.\r\n* Mentors: @jgbarah , @valeriocos \r\n\r\n## Microtasks\r\n\r\nFor becoming familiar with the GitLab technology, it is useful if you produce an analysis (Elasticsearch indexes and dashboard) for a GitHub project (git repos and GitHub issues and pull requests). Have a look at the "Before you start" chapter in the [GrimoireLab tutorial](https://grimoirelab.gitbooks.io/tutorial) to learn how to install the needed infrastructure (ElasticSearch, Kibiter, MariaDB) and GrimoireLab itself as Python packages, or how to deploy everything as a Docker container.\r\n\r\nOnce you're familiar with producing analysis, you can try to automatically produce the list of repositories to analyze, in several ways:\r\n\r\n* Microtask 1: Produce a Python script that produces configuration files for Mordred to analyze a complete GitHub organization, excluding repositories that are forks from other GitHub repositories. Test it with at least two GitHub organizations, producing screenshots of the resulting dashboard.\r\n\r\n* Microtask 2: Produce a Python script that adds a new GitHub repository (git and GitHub issues / pull requests) to a given set of Mordred configuration files. Test it by adding at least two repositories (in two separate steps) to a GrimoireLab dashboard, producing screenshots of the results.\r\n\r\n* Microtask 3: Produce a Python script that removes a GitHub repository  (git and GitHub issues / pull requests) from a working GrimoireLab dashboard, by modifying the needed Mordred configuration files, and fixing the raw and enriched indexes to remove the items for the removed repository. Test it by removing at least two repositories (in two separate steps) from a GrimoireLab dashboard, producing screenshots of the results.\r\n\r\n* Microtask 4: Perform any other modification of Mordred configuration files that you may find useful, showing screenshots of how that affects the resulting dashboard.\r\n\r\nIf you want, you can also:\r\n\r\n* Microtask 5: Produce a pull request for any of the GrimoireLab tools, and try to follow instructions until it gets accepted. Try do do something simple that you consider useful, not necessarily fix to the code: improvement of comments, documentation or testing will usually be easier to get accepted, and very useful for the project. Please, avoid just producing a random pull request just to have another microtask: the objective is not that you get one more microtask done, but that you understand how to interact with developers in the project contributing with something that could be useful).\r\n\r\nOf course, there is no need to do all the microtasks, you only need to show that your skills are in good standing for working in this project.\r\n\r\n## Showing the work you did\r\n\r\nIf you want to show the work you did, open a GitHub repository, and upload to it:\r\n\r\n* A `README.md` file explaining what you did, and linking to the results (which will be in the same repository, see below). This will be the main file to show your skills and interest on the project, so try to make it organized and clear, in a way that we can easily understand what you did.\r\n\r\n* Screenshots of the dashboard(s) you produced, and configuration files you used for them (if any). Please remember removing passwords and/or auth tokens that could be in them, before uploading. In the `REAME.md` file, link all those files, telling about which GitHub projects you analyzed.\r\n\r\n* Python scripts and/or Python Jupyter notebooks you produced, with enough information (in comments and/or in the `README.md` file) so that we can run them if needed. Upload Python scripts ready to work assuming GrimoireLab packages are already installed. Upload Jupyter notebooks ready to be seen via the GitHub web interface.\r\n\r\n* Links to the pull request you did (if any), along with any comment you may have about it.\r\n\r\n## Submitting information for the application process\r\n\r\n* You must complete at least one micro-task related to the idea you are interested on.\r\n\r\n* Once you completed at least one micro-task, go to the governance repository and create a pull request to add yourself, your information, and a link to your repository with the completed micro-task(s) in the [GSoC-interest.md file](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-interest.md) (see above for the contents of the repository).\r\n\r\n* You are welcome to include in your repository other information that could be of interest, such as open issues or pull requests submitted to the project to which you intend to contribute during GSoC, contributions to other projects, skills, and other related information.\r\n\r\n* You must complete these things by March 27 16:00 UTC. Make sure to also submit the information required by GSoC for applicants (i.e., project proposal), linking to it from your pull request in the [GSoC-interest.md file](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-interest.md).\r\n\r\n* [Message to the mailing list with guidelines on proposals](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/oss-health-metrics/2018-March/000532.html).\r\n\r\n## Useful documentation\r\n\r\n* [GrimoireLab Tutorial](https://grimoirelab.gitbooks.io/tutorial)\r\n\r\n* [CHAOSS Metrics](https://wiki.linuxfoundation.org/chaoss/metrics#chaoss-oss-project-metrics) (work in progress)\r\n\r\n## Asking for help\r\n\r\nIf you need help, please use the following channels.\r\n\r\nFor issues related to GrimoireLab:\r\n\r\n* Comments in this issue\r\n* #grimoirelab channel in [Freenode IRC](https://freenode.net/)\r\n* [GrimoireLab mailing list](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/mailman/listinfo/grimoirelab-discussions) \r\n\r\nFor general issues related to CHAOSS or CHAOSS metrics\r\n\r\n* #chaoss-community channel in [Freenode IRC](https://freenode.net/)\r\n* [CHAOSS mailing list](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/mailman/listinfo/oss-health-metrics) (please use the tag "\\[GSoC\\]" in the subject line).\r\n	277192	73	2018-09-11 21:01:30	2018-09-11 21:01:30	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/71	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/71/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/71/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/71/events	https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/issues/71	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUyOTc5MDI5NDU=	297902945	1039693	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:17:29	71

337173	25432	277110	\N	\N	2019-02-04 18:05:42	GSoC Idea: Implementing CHAOSS Metrics in Augur	# Ideas for Google Summer of Code projects\r\n\r\n## Idea 5: Build CHAOSS Risk and Growth Maturity and Decline Metrics in Augur\r\n\r\n### Description\r\n\r\n[Augur](http://www.augurlabs.io) is a fully functional prototyping web stack for CHAOSS metrics that leverages cutting edge web technologies including VUE, NodeJS and Python. It provides structured data mined from git repositories using a plugin architecture that incorporate other open source metrics projects like [Facade](http://facade-oss.org/) and [FOSSology](https://www.fossology.org/). \r\n\r\nIn this GSoC project we plan to implement Risk metrics and other metrics within the Growth-Maturity-Decline [CHAOSS metrics and use cases](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-gmd) using Augur, focusing on what we have unearthed as the open source community manager use case. The aims of the project are to: \r\n1. Construct core open source software metrics defined by CHAOSS and\r\n2. Assemble filtered, comparative collections of those metrics in ways that community managers want to consume. \r\n\r\nThe aims of the project are as follows:\r\n\r\n  * Acquiring knowledge on Augur toolchain to generate metrics from available data sources.  \r\n  * Creating VUE visualizations and API's to support the enumerated metrics and metric collections. \r\n  * Writing Python code to query Facade, Augur and other datasets. \r\n\r\nRight now, based on Augur prototypes and follow up discussions so far, we have the following observations that will inform our work both the “Growth Maturity and Decline” working group and in Augur Development. Here are a few things we have learned from prototyping Augur with community managers. These features in Augur are particularly valued:\r\n1. Allowing comparisons with projects within a defined universe of of projects is essential\r\n2. Allow community managers to add and remove repositories that they monitor from their repertories periodically\r\n3. Downloadable graphics\r\n4. Downloadable data (.csv or .json)\r\n5. Availability of a “Metrics API”, limiting the amount of software infrastructure the community manager needs to maintain for themselves. This is more valued by program managers overseeing larger portfolios right now, but we think it has potential to grow as awareness of the relatively light weight of this approach becomes more apparent. By apparent, we really mean “easy to use and understand”; right now it is easy for a programmer, but less so for a community manager without this background or current interest.\r\n\r\nWith these advantages in mind, making the most of this opportunity to help community managers with useful metrics is going to include the availability of date summarized comparison metrics. These types of metrics have two “filters” or “parameters” fed into them that are more abstractly defined in the Growth, Maturity, and Decline metrics on the CHAOSS project.\r\n\r\n1. Given a pool of repositories of interest for a community manager, rank them in ascending or descending order by a metric\r\n2. Over a specified time period or\r\n3. Over a specified periodicity (e.g., month) for a length of time (e.g., year).\r\n\r\nFor example, one open source program officer we talked with is interested in the following set of date summarized comparison metrics. Given a pool of repositories of interest to the program officer (dozens to hundreds of repositories):\r\n1. What ten repositories have the most commits this year (straight commits, and lines of code)?\r\n2. How many new projects were launched this year?\r\n3. What are the top ten new repositories in terms of commits this year (straight commits, and lines of code)?\r\n4. How many commits and lines of code were contributed by outside contributors this calendar year? Organizationally sponsored contributors?\r\n5. What organizations are the top five external contributors of commits, comments, and merges?\r\n6. What are the total number of repository watchers we have across all of our projects?\r\n7. Which repositories have the most stars? Of the ones new this year? Of all the projects? Which projects have the most new stars this year?\r\n\r\nFurther elaboration on the community manager use case is available on the CHAOSS website: [Community Manager Metrics Use Case](https://chaoss.community/news/2018/11/16/metrics-with-greater-utility-the-community-manager-use-case/)\r\n\r\n  * _Difficulty:_ Medium\r\n  * _Requirements:_ Python programming. Interest in data analytics. Willingness to understand data structures and our web stack internals and CHAOSS metrics.\r\n  * _Recommended:_ Experience : NodeJS Programming. VUE Programming.\r\n  * _Mentors:_ Sean Goggins, Jesus M. Gonzalez-Barahona\r\n\r\n## Microtasks\r\n\r\n - **Microtask 0**: Familiarize yourself with [augur](http://www.github.com/chaoss/augur) by downloading and configuring the dev branch. For a little more context about what we are trying to accomplish with Augur's prototyping, checkout the blog posts on the [Augur Website](http://www.augurlabs.io). The community manager use case is especially interesting. \r\n - **Microtask 1**: Using the Augur reference database included in the setup, configure a new metric from those available an not implemented in the ["Metrics Status" page](http://dev.augurlabs.io/metrics_status).\r\n - **Microstask 2**: If you want, take a look at the configuration for VUE cards in the frontend/ folder for augur, google Vue, and see what kinds of new visualizations you might want to try out for some of the already existing metrics. \r\n - **Microtask 3**: Make a pull request to update the newcomer documentation or, if you have questions about getting started in the steps above, open an issue in the Augur repository.  	277192	6	2019-06-05 14:39:26	2019-06-05 14:39:25	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/82	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/82/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/82/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/82/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/82	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MDY0NTEyOTY=	406451296	379847	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:22:47	82

337006	25432	277268	\N	\N	2019-07-07 20:10:41	[GSoC] The need for passing `df` as a parameter to `_agg` method	As pointed out in a comment by @jgbarah [here](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/pull/194#discussion_r300644522). \r\n\r\nThe `time_series` method in the Metric (root) class goes like this:\r\n```python\r\n    def time_series(self, period='M'):\r\n        df = self.df\r\n\r\n        df = df.set_index('created_date')\r\n        df = self._agg(df, period)\r\n\r\n        return df\r\n```\r\nIn the implementation we have, if we use `self.df` directly in `_agg`, there is not much point in having the `time_series` method, since we would now be creating and modifying `df` inside `_agg`.\r\n\r\nThis issue serves as a reminder to look for a better solution, if necessary. 	277118	1	2019-08-28 15:00:00	2019-08-28 15:00:00	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/201	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/201/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/201/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/201/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/201	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0NjQ5ODgyMjc=	464988227	31214064	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:19:33	201

337015	25432	277268	\N	\N	2019-06-28 16:32:05	[GSoC] Separating column selection and aggregation in time_series method	This issue has been opened to address the problem of separating column selection and aggregation. The aim is to perform an aggregation operation on a DataFrame after resampling it into buckets of a fixed time interval, like a week or a month. \r\nA rough idea would be:\r\n```python\r\ndf = df.resample('W)['col_1'].agg('count')\r\n```\r\nThis becomes really specific since every metric reference implementation will have its own selection of columns as well as its own aggregation function. \r\nA solution to address this issue is required. 	277118	1	2019-08-28 15:00:31	2019-08-28 15:00:31	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/192	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/192/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/192/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/192/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/192	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0NjIxMTY2NTk=	462116659	31214064	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:19:42	192

337054	25432	277268	\N	\N	2019-05-25 08:27:18	[GSoC] Re-implementing the Code_changes-git metric	As discussed with @jgbarah and @aswanipranjal in the IRC meeting on the 24th of May (log can be found [here](https://github.com/Polaris000/GSoC_19_Perceval_Implementations/blob/master/IRC_chats/may_24_comm_bonding.txt), and blog post [here](https://polaris000.github.io/blog/com_bonding_2)), a new structure for reference implementations is being tried out:  \r\n\r\nCreate a class for the analysis of reference implementations with several methods, the most important being a method which would calculate a single value for the metric. Some other\r\n```python\r\n  class MetricCompute(Period, Source_Code_criteria):\r\n\r\n      # generate a value for the metric\r\n      method1: compute(self, data) \r\n\r\n      # generate a value for each period: like one per week/month\r\n      method2: compute_time_series(self, data, period)\r\n\r\n      # generate charts / graphs regarding the metric\r\n      optional: generate_graphs(self, data, ..)\r\n```\r\nmethods can be added depending on the metric to create charts or graphs. This notebook will be used to generate a script, which would be tested against some sample Perceval JSON data. Then a user can import this as a module to run it on their own data. \r\n\r\nSince this method is still under evaluation, it was decided that I would implement this metric using the new method in my [project-tracker/experiment repo](https://github.com/Polaris000/GSoC_19_Perceval_Implementations). If this proves to be effective (and I am sure it will :) ), other metrics will  be implemented this way. \r\n\r\nPlease drop your ideas and suggestions below!	277192	0	2019-06-18 10:07:36	2019-06-18 10:07:36	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/153	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/153/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/153/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/153/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/153	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0NDg0Mzg1NTQ=	448438554	31214064	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:20:33	153

337058	25432	277317	\N	\N	2018-11-14 07:06:08	Use case: Characterize a participant, both within a given project and across projects.	This may be a long-ish description -- I'm porting a formerly private conversation with @jgbarah over to here.  (If there's some more appropriate forum, please let me know!)\r\n\r\nTo set some context: almost all the information I'd want to find out about a project is actually built up from the activity of the *people* in that project, so I've come to think that most of the metrics I'm looking for are about people primarily, and projects secondarily.\r\n\r\n* **Use Case:** Evaluate whether a person should be offered commit access or whatever the equivalent is for the kind of work they're doing (e.g., maybe it's actually "a vote on the steering committee" or "an editorship position in the documentation" or whatever).  The point is, existing maintainers often find themselves evaluating a person's activity in order to determine whether that person should be invited into some kind of formal maintainer role.\r\n\r\n  The metrics required to do this thoroughly are interesting:\r\n\r\n  - The data collection system needs a concept of the person's unified identity.  I.e., this account over here in the repository (which may or may not use the same authn system as the issue tracker) is the same as that account over there in the wiki... is the same person as these two email addresses on the mailing list... all of which are the same person as so-and-so over in the chat platform, etc, etc.  (Obviously it will not always be possible to determine these correspondences automatically, so there needs to be a UI where some knowledgeable human can come in and just *tell* the system that two accounts both belong to the same person, after which the system can faithfully remember that fact.)\r\n  - A time-based view of when the person is active.  I almost care *that* they are active more than *how* they're active.  It's hard to tell, in an automated way, whether a given commit was more of a contribution than an answer given in Zulip or IRC, for example.  But just looking at *when* and *how often* the person did stuff tells you a lot.\r\n  - When the person is responding to someone else in a thread (whether it be in the issue tracker, mailing list, or somewhere else), what is the range of latencies of the person's responses?\r\n\r\nSo that's what I want: an ability to look at a list of participants in a project, and see what they've been up to.  Looking at a person's activity within a single project would already be useful.  Ideally, I'd like to look at that person's activity in as many projects as possible.  For example:\r\n\r\n* **Use Case:** If I knew that a particular bug reporter had a tendency to report bugs that resulted in associated bug fixes that were successfully merged, with the ticket closed as "FIXED" (or whatever the equivalent state is in that tracker), then when that person reported a bug in my project, I might pay attention more quickly.\r\n\r\nI'm carefully avoiding getting into project health metrics for the moment, but expect that they would largely grow out of person-based metrics.  And there are many more person-based metrics we could all think of, of course; the ones above are just a start.  The prerequisite for all person-based metrics is a unified identity tracking system, I think.	277110	13	2019-08-14 14:54:14	2019-08-14 14:54:13	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/48	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/48/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/48/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/48/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/48	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzODA1NjMzODg=	380563388	401111	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:20:37	48

337073	25432	277307	\N	\N	2018-10-30 17:19:17	Use Case: Efficiency in reviewing contributions from first-time contributors	A first-time contributor could be easily discouraged if no one reviews/acknowledges their work in a timely manner. Following are number of questions that can help evaluate responsiveness for first-time contributors. \r\n\r\n- What percentage of first-time contributions are accepted?\r\n- What percentage of contributions from first-time contributors are accepted vs. `core developers`?\r\n- How long does it take (e.g. average or median) for first-time contributions to be `resolved` (e.g. accepted or declined)?\r\n- How long does it take (e.g. average or median) for contributions from `core developers` to be `resolved` (e.g. accepted or declined)?\r\n- How long does it take (e.g. average or media) for first-time contributions to be responded to (e.g. acknowledgment, first review, etc.)? \r\n- How long does it take (e.g. average or median) for contributions from `core developers` to be responded to (e.g. acknowledgment, first review, etc.)? \r\n- Does the acceptance of first-time contribution have an effect on future contributions from the same contributor? \r\n- Does the responsiveness to first-time contribution (e.g. average/median time for acknowledgement, first review, etc.) have an effect on future contributions from the same contributor? 	277307	20	2019-02-01 13:39:14	2019-02-01 13:39:13	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/33	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/33/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/33/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/33/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/33	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzNzU2MDM4MzQ=	375603834	10257798	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:20:53	33

337081	25432	277148	\N	\N	2018-10-06 00:49:51	Standardized names for entities 	From Mailing List\r\n\r\n**dmg**\r\n\r\nI would like to suggest that as part of CHAOSS, there is also an attempt to standardize how to call an entity\r\nin a repository/database. Note these are not the names of the entities, but their abbreviations.\r\n\r\nThis is what I mean:\r\n\r\n1. Entities.\r\nA commit has a commit id,  "author" and a "committer" and a  authorship-date, and a committing date.\r\nWhat should we call them?\r\n\r\ncregit calls them: cid, author, committer, autdate, comdate,\r\na subderived entity: we prefix with an identifier:\r\n   author => autemail, autname\r\n\r\n2. Counts.\r\n\r\nWhat should counts be called? We prefix the entity with n;\r\nncommits, nauthor, nfiles, etc.\r\n\r\n**Manrique**\r\nIt sounds like a reasonable expectation, so thanks Daniel for opening the discussion.\r\n\r\nFrom time to time I have been thinking about proposing schema.org as baseline vocabulary.\r\n\r\nThere are some already defined that could be interesting to check:\r\n\r\nhttps://schema.org/Person\r\nhttps://schema.org/SoftwareSourceCode\r\nhttps://schema.org/Organization\r\nhttps://schema.org/Comment\r\nhttps://schema.org/Dataset\r\nhttps://schema.org/DataFeed\r\nhttps://schema.org/Question\r\n\r\nI think most of software development related activity couybe mapped to CreativeWork concept:\r\nhttps://schema.org/CreativeWork\r\n\r\nPerhaps my Semantic Web "background" is always trying to find a place for all these years of standardizing vocabularies. Another potential interested approach is SIOC:\r\nhttp://rdfs.org/sioc/spec/\r\n\r\nOf course, we should agree about names and what they mean. For example, "commit", can be interpreted very differently:\r\nhttps://blog.bitergia.com/2014/03/07/commits-that-metric/	277148	2	2018-10-31 15:23:05	2018-10-31 15:23:05	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/25	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/25/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/25/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/25/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/25	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzNjc0MDgxMTA=	367408110	10539189	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:21:03	25

337091	25432	277280	\N	\N	2018-07-02 21:58:22	Development Velocity Meta Metric	Based on the discussions we had in the working group meeting last week. Here is my proposed meta-metric (super-metric) for development velocity.\r\n\r\n# Background\r\nWhen evaluating the success of an open source community, one of the most basic things to evaluate is how quickly new code or content is produced and merged into the mainline project, and whether this rate is increasing, decreasing, or staying constant.\r\n\r\n# Components\r\n* Code Commits\r\n* Code Merge Duration\r\n\r\n# Outcome\r\n**Development Speed:** fast, slow, halted. This meta-metric can either be relative and compare two separate projects (i.e which project is faster/slower) or two points in time for the same project, or it can be based on an established baseline that is specific to the project, technology, or software development practices at large. \r\n**Development Acceleration:** accelerating, decelerating, constant. This is a relative meta-metric that compares the development speed at two points in time for the same project.\r\n\r\n# Use Cases:\r\nA community manager wants to evaluate the impact of hosting a series of developer events to see if development activity is increasing as a result of them.\r\n\r\nA strategist or software architect is evaluating multiple open source components to integrate into company projects. They want to identify which community has a greater level of development activity and whether each project is increasing or decreasing in activity.\r\n\r\n# Example Value Statements\r\n* Development is fast, but decelerating.\r\n* Development is slow and has been constant for 3 months.\r\n* Development is slower than it was last year, but is accelerating.\r\n* Development has stalled for 6 months.\r\n* Development of project A is faster than development of project B.\r\n\r\n# Formula\r\n**Development Speed:** (Code Commits) / (Code Merge Duration). This factors both component metrics and expresses a number that is higher for projects that have larger number of commits and smaller lengths of time to get code committed. I.e. faster projects have a higher number. \r\n\r\n**Development Acceleration** - This simply compares development speed from two different points in time.	277280	9	2018-11-06 08:44:38	2018-11-06 01:43:53	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/15	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/15/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/15/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/15/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/15	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzMzc2NzgwODc=	337678087	7205829	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:21:15	15

337092	25432	277273	\N	\N	2018-06-16 07:33:21	Who can be considered a maintainer for a project?	AFAIK a maintainer is a user who has PUSH privileges to a codebase and how can approve of the changes made by other users. Currently the users are being divided into:  None, Owner, Collaborator, Contributor and Member. Out of these, I think Only Owner of the repo can be considered as a maintainer because they'll be deciding which code is included into the project or not.\r\n\r\nApart from that, we can set some conditions that if a user X has contributed Y times to a project and is active in solving issues then they can be considered as a maintainer.\r\n\r\nWe can also set a condition such as `Issues.First:_Response(maintainers=['Owner', 'Memberr'])` as Jesus @jgbarah suggested [here during our meeting](https://github.com/aswanipranjal/gsoc-manuscripts/blob/master/IRC-transcripts/IRC-chat-13-06-2018.txt#L182). \r\n[Start of the discussion](https://github.com/aswanipranjal/gsoc-manuscripts/blob/master/IRC-transcripts/IRC-chat-13-06-2018.txt#L151).\r\n\r\nThis is relevant because for calculating #8 , we need to know who the maintainer is.	277192	3	2018-10-31 11:13:52	2018-10-31 11:13:52	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/14	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/14/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/14/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/14/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/14	closed	MDU6SXNzdWUzMzI5NjgxMDE=	332968101	9946566	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:21:17	14

337117	25432	277192	\N	\N	2019-04-09 22:14:59	[focus_areas] Feedback on how to measure efficiency	In the [code development focus area](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-gmd/blob/master/focus_areas/code_development.md), one of the specific goals is "Eficiency". Now, we have it defined as:\r\n\r\n> Efficiency: Learning how effective new code is merged into the code base\r\n\r\nFirst of all, I think we should extend this definition to how efficient are the processes that the project follows in the area of code development. I propose to change this short definition to:\r\n\r\n> Efficiency: Learning how efficient are processes directly related to code development.\r\n\r\nWhat do you think about this?\r\n\r\nThen, we have several questions for this goal, which already consider this extended definition somehow. They refer to efficiency in considering proposals for change (how efficient is the code review process), and in dealing with issues related to code development. What do you think about this. Should we consider something else? What do you think about the specific metrics defined for these questions? 337119	25432	277268	\N	\N	2019-04-08 14:33:17	[feature] Testing repositories based on reference implementations	As mentioned in passing by @jgbarah,  a possible tool to automatically evaluate repositories based on metrics would be quite useful. \r\n\r\nIf this feature is not of immediate importance, we could always work on it later,  but if it is, I'd love everyone's views on it.\r\n\r\nI see two ways of going about it:\r\n\r\n1. create a command line based tool with python which takes Perceval data and generates an output file with information based on the metrics chosen, for example, number of issues, number of new contributors over several time frames, etc.\r\n**advantages**: its easier to pass arguments to a python script using the command line\r\n**disadvantages**: It will lack the neat organization of jupyter notebooks, since it is a python script\r\n\r\n2. Use the reference implementation notebooks of metrics and then generalize them in such that they read data from a config file, which is generated by a python script based on the parameters passed by a user. When the script is run, the notebooks will run on Perceval data and display required data in the form of a jupyter notebook (like a regular reference implementation).\r\n**advantages**: Analysis is well organized in the form of a jupyter notebook\r\n**disadvantages**: ipython notebooks don't work to well with imports and as of now, I have n't found a way to directly pass arguments from a command line to a jupyter notebook, hence, the config file.\r\n\r\n	277118	12	2019-08-28 16:09:34	2019-08-28 14:59:09	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/136	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/136/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/136/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/136/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/136	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MzA0ODYyNzc=	430486277	31214064	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:21:47	136

337121	25432	277113	\N	\N	2019-04-07 17:12:20	Definition of "Abandoned Issues"	I was trying to implement the metric "[Issues Resolution Efficiency](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-gmd/blob/master/metrics/issues-closed-resolution-efficiency.md)" in Augur and came across "Abandoned Issues." Currently, there is no definition for "Abandoned Issues." \r\n\r\nI had a bit of a discussion with @sgoggins related to this resulting in the following definition "**open X days without communication for Y days**."\r\n\r\nAnother definition could be "**Opened issues with X days of inactivity**." This definition is based on what [probot-stale](https://github.com/probot/stale#usage) uses to mark issues as abandoned.\r\n\r\nLets decide to use a particular definition.	277113	10	2019-05-22 14:57:04	2019-05-22 14:51:12	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/134	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/134/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/134/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/134/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/134	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MzAxNjk1NTI=	430169552	22260291	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:21:50	134
