337174	25432	277192	\N	\N	2019-01-31 17:42:07	GSoC Idea: Implementing CHAOSS metrics with Perceval	[ This issue for addressing questions and comments related to this GSoC idea, which is one of [the ideas proposed by the CHAOSS group](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-Ideas.md) for the 2019 edition of GSoC.]\r\n\r\n## Description\r\n\r\nThe [GMD Working group](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-gmd) is proposing some metrics\r\nthat are computed with information obtained from software development repositories.\r\nOne of the goals of the working group is to provide reference implementations of\r\nthose metrics, based on the output produced by [Perceval](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval).\r\nAs an example, still work in progress, check the Python notebook with the\r\n[reference implementation for changes to the source code](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-gmd/blob/master/implementations/Code_Changes-Git.ipynb).\r\n\r\nThe aims of this idea are as follows:\r\n\r\n* Producing Python (Jupyter) notebooks with proposals for reference implementations\r\nfor these metrics. The proposals will follow the usual acceptance mechanism of the working group\r\n(based on GitHub issues and pull requests). In general, all reference implementations will\r\nbuild on the output produced by Perceval for the relevant data source,\r\nand will explore the peculiarities of the metric and its implementation for that data source.\r\n\r\n* Document the notebooks as much as possible, so that any person trying to implement the metric\r\ncan understand not only how to implement it, but also the details that should have into account.\r\nDocumentation should also be suitable for people willing to dig deeper about the details of\r\nthe metric, with the aim of understanding it (not necesarily implementing it).\r\n\r\n* When needed, propose changes to Perceval, and maybe other components in GrimoireLab,\r\nthat allow for the implementation of the metric.\r\n\r\n* Participate in the acceptance process of the working group.\r\n\r\nThe aims will require programming in Python, producing Python notebooks, interaction with other\r\npeople in the working group to learn about subtle details of the metrics, and producing\r\ndocumentation.\r\n\r\n* _Difficulty:_ Medium\r\n* _Requirements:_ Python programming, experience with Python notebooks, skills for producing documentation.\r\n* _Recommended:_ Experience in data analytics with Python, if possible involving the use of Pandas, will be a plus. \r\n* _Mentors:_ @jgbarah and @valeriocos.\r\n\r\n## Microtasks\r\n\r\nFor becoming familiar with Perceval, it is useful if you produce retrieve data from several repositories or a FOSS (free, open source software) project, and produce some kind of analysis and/or summary of results, in a [Jupyter Notebook](https://jupyter.org/). You can start by browsing the [GrimoireLab Tutorial](https://chaoss.github.io/grimoirelab-tutorial/), and in particular, the [chapter on Perceval](https://chaoss.github.io/grimoirelab-tutorial/perceval/intro.html).\r\n\r\nOnce you're familiar with producing analysis, you can exploit the information in the indexes via a Python script presented as a Python Jupyter Notebook. For showing it, you can make it work with [MyBinder](https://mybinder.org/), and show us its MyBinder link. For the data to be presented in the analysis, you can run Perceval on any FOSS project with at least 5 GitHub or GitLab repositories which include git (at least 1,000 commits in total), issues (at least 200 issues in total) and pull requests / merge requests (at least 200 pull requests / merge requests in total).\r\n\r\n* Microtask 0: Use this [notebook implementing the Code_Changes metric](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-gmd/blob/master/implementations/Code_Changes-Git.ipynb) ([see it in MyBinder](https://mybinder.org/v2/gh/chaoss/wg-gmd/master?filepath=implementations/Code_Changes-Git.ipynb)) as an example of how to collect the data, producing a single JSON file per data source, with all items (commits, issues,  pull/merge requests) in it. Produce one notebook per data source (git, GitHub/GitLab issues, GitHub pull requests / GitLab merge requests) showing a summary of the contents of that file (number of items in it, and number of different identities in it counting authors/committers for git, submitters for issues and pull/merge requests). This microtask is mandatory, to show that you can retrieve data and produde a notebook showing it. In each notebook, include also the list of repositories retrieved, and the date of retrieval, using data available in the JSON file.\r\n\r\n* Microtask 1: Produce a notebook showing (and producing) a list with the activity per quarter: number of new committers, submitters of issues, and submitters of pull/merge requests, number of items (commits, issues, pull/merge requests), number of repositories with new items (all of this per quarter) as a table and as a CSV file. Use plain Python3 (eg, no Pandas) for this.\r\n\r\n* Microtask 2: Like Microtask 1, but now using [Pandas](http://pandas.pydata.org/).\r\n\r\n* Microtask 3: Produce a notebook with charts showing the distribution of time-to-close for issues already closed, and opened during the last year, for each of the repositories analyzed, and for all of them together. Use Pandas for this, and the Python charting library of your choice (as long as it is a FOSS module).\r\n\r\n* Microtask 4: Produce a listing of repositories, as a table and as CSV file, with the number of commits authored, issues opened, and pull/merge requests opened, during the last three months, ordered by the total number (commits plus issues plus pull requests). Use plain Python3 (eg, no Pandas) for this.\r\n\r\n* Microtask 5: Like Microtask 4, but now using [Pandas](http://pandas.pydata.org/).\r\n\r\n* Microtask 6: Perform any other analysis you may find interesting, based on the Perceval data you collected.\r\n\r\nIf you want, you can also:\r\n\r\n* Microtask 7: Produce a pull request for any of the GrimoireLab tools, and try to follow instructions until it gets accepted. Try do do something simple that you consider useful, not necessarily fix to the code: improvement of comments, documentation or testing will usually be easier to get accepted, and very useful for the project. Please, avoid just producing a random pull request just to have another microtask: the objective is not that you get one more microtask done, but that you understand how to interact with developers in the project contributing with something that could be useful).\r\n\r\n* Microtask 8: Like Microtask 7, but for the GMD working group. You may try to fix some error (even grammatical) in the description of a metric, improve the description of a focus area, fix or improve a reference implementation, or even produce a new reference implementation proposal. As in the previous microtask, the goal is not that your contribution is accepted (which of course would be great), or that you just complete yet another microtask, but that you interact with the working group, and you understand its context and procedures.\r\n \r\nOf course, there is no need to do all the microtasks, you only need to show that your skills are in good standing for working in this project.\r\n\r\n## Showing the work you did\r\n\r\nIf you want to show the work you did, open a GitHub repository, and upload to it:\r\n\r\n* A `README.md` file explaining what you did, and linking to the results (which will be in the same repository, see below). This will be the main file to show your skills and interest on the project, so try to make it organized and clear, in a way that we can easily understand what you did.\r\n\r\n* Python Jupyter notebooks you produced, with enough information (in comments and/or in the `README.md` file) so that we can run them if needed. Upload Python scripts ready to work assuming GrimoireLab packages are already installed. Upload Jupyter notebooks ready to be seen via the GitHub web interface, but also include links to fully-functional versions of the notebooks in MyBinder.\r\n\r\n* Links to the pull request you did (if any), along with any comment you may have about it.\r\n\r\n## Submitting information for the application process\r\n\r\n* You must complete at least microtask 0, and at least three microtasks, in the case you're interested in this idea.\r\n\r\n* Once you completed at least one microtask, go to the governance repository and create a pull request to add yourself, your information, and a link to your repository with the completed micro-task(s) in the [GSoC-interest.md file](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-interest.md) (see above for the contents of the repository).\r\n\r\n* You are welcome to include in your repository other information that could be of interest, such as open issues or pull requests submitted to the project to which you intend to contribute during GSoC, contributions to other projects, skills, and other related information.\r\n\r\n* You must complete these things by GSoC deadline for proposals. Make sure to also submit the information required by GSoC for applicants (i.e., project proposal), linking to it from your pull request in the [GSoC-interest.md file](https://github.com/chaoss/governance/blob/master/GSoC-interest.md).\r\n\r\n## Useful documentation\r\n\r\n* [GrimoireLab Tutorial](https://chaoss.github.io/grimoirelab-tutorial/)\r\n\r\n## Getting feedback for your proposal & microtasks\r\n\r\nOur idea is to have a look at proposals that are registered in the governance repository starting after 25th March, when students can formally apply. But if you have specific doubts, comments, or whatever, use this issue.\r\n\r\nIn general, we don't want to give advice too specific to one case, because that could give some advantage to some person with respect to the others. Answering questions and addressing comments (if you want, based on your proposal) is not a problem as long as that's done in public, hence the threads in this issue.\r\n\r\n## Asking for help\r\n\r\nIf you need help, please use the following channels.\r\n\r\nFor issues related to GrimoireLab:\r\n\r\n* Comments in this issue\r\n* #grimoirelab channel in [Freenode IRC](https://freenode.net/)\r\n* [GrimoireLab mailing list](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/mailman/listinfo/grimoirelab-discussions) \r\n\r\nFor general issues related to CHAOSS or CHAOSS metrics\r\n\r\n* #chaoss-community channel in [Freenode IRC](https://freenode.net/)\r\n* [CHAOSS mailing list](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/mailman/listinfo/chaoss) (please use the tag "\\[GSoC\\]" in the subject line)	277192	82	2019-06-05 14:39:47	2019-06-05 14:39:46	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/81	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/81/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/81/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/81/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/81	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MDUzNjE5NzM=	405361973	1039693	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:22:49	81

337145	25432	277192	\N	\N	2019-03-20 13:14:53	[metrics] "Reviews" instead of "Proposals"?	Some people have pointed out that the name "Proposals" is difficult to map to pull requests, merge requests or code reviews, and that "proposals" is not used in this context.\r\n\r\nProposals came from "proposals of changes to the code", but I agree that the word "proposals", isolated, is difficult to map to a code review process. It is the name we're currently used in the code development focus area (file [code_development.md](https://github.com/chaoss/wg-gmd/blob/master/focus_areas/code_development.md)).\r\n\r\nThus, I propose to change "Proposals" for "Reviews", which would be much more explicit, and would still include pull requests in the case of GitHub, merge requests in the case of GitLab, and code reviews in the case of Gerrit.\r\n\r\nThe change would be in all metrics names, such as "Proposals" -> "Reviews", or "Proposals_Accepted" -> "Reviews_Accepted".\r\n\r\nIf nobody opposes, I will produce the pull request for that (or anyone who has some time could do it ,-) ).\r\n\r\nAny feedback is welcome!!	277110	9	2019-04-24 15:07:33	2019-04-24 15:07:33	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/110	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/110/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/110/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/110/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/110	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MjMyNDQyMzE=	423244231	1039693	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:22:17	110
337146	25432	277126	\N	\N	2019-03-19 16:50:48	require DCO for all new commits	This issue is to activate [protobot/dco](https://github.com/apps/dco) (or similar bot) to check that all commits have a sign-off. The CHAOSS Project Charter requires that all contributions are signed-off. \r\n\r\nFor users of the git command line interface, a sign-off is accomplished with the `-s` as part of the commit command: `git commit -s -m 'This is a commit message'`\r\n\r\nFor users of the GitHub interface, a sign-off is accomplished by writing `Signed-off-by: Your Name <YourName@example.org>` into the commit comment field. This can be automated by using a browser plugin like [scottrigby/dco-gh-ui](https://github.com/)\r\n	277126	15	2019-03-29 14:52:19	2019-03-27 14:39:40	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/109	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/109/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/109/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/109/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-evolution/issues/109	closed	MDU6SXNzdWU0MjI4NDI2NzY=	422842676	8862021	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:22:19	109

337194	25432	277317	\N	\N	2018-12-13 05:50:36	Use case: Characterize a bug reporter's past success at effectively reporting bugs.	This grows out of discussion in issue #48:\r\n\r\n* **Use Case:** If I knew that a particular bug reporter had a tendency to report bugs that resulted in associated bug fixes that were successfully merged, with the ticket closed as "FIXED" (or whatever the equivalent state is in that tracker), then when that person reported a bug in my project, I might pay attention more quickly.\r\n\r\nHmm.  You know, I think it might actually be that simple. 337207	25433	277245	\N	\N	2019-10-10 16:15:11	Wrong formula for Elephant Factor? 	Looking at the description of this metric I'd say the formula is not correct.\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/chaoss/wg-risk/blob/e7cea7034d65c65a3658d16a434b9868e52b2306/metrics/Elephant_Factor.md#L5-L9\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/chaoss/wg-risk/blob/e7cea7034d65c65a3658d16a434b9868e52b2306/metrics/Elephant_Factor.md#L10-L22\r\n\r\nAs far as I understand, the description is correct while the formula is calculating a different thing. If we had the following companies and commits:\r\n\r\nCompany | Commits\r\n---|---\r\nA | 1\r\nB | 2\r\nC | 3\r\nD | 4\r\nE | 100\r\n\r\nIt's clear to me that the EF should be 1 (E) because is contributing more than 50% of commits (if we parametrize EF to that percentage, of course). This results from ordering companies by number of commits (E, D, C, B, A) and start adding commits from the one with more commits (E) until reaching the 50% of total contributions.\r\n\r\nSo, 50% of total contributions is `(100 + 4 + 3 + 2 + 1) * 0.5 = 55` and once we add commits made by E company we already reach the threshold (`100 > 55`), so EF is 1.\r\n\r\nFollowing the formula, the median would be 3 and the EF would be 2 (D and E), when D is clearly not involved in the higher 50% of contributions.\r\n\r\n\r\n	\N	0	2019-10-10 16:15:11	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-risk	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-risk/issues/46	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-risk/issues/46/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-risk/issues/46/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-risk/issues/46/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-risk/issues/46	open	MDU6SXNzdWU1MDUzNzM3OTE=	505373791	3502941	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:23:38	46

337251	25433	277126	\N	\N	2019-03-25 18:39:47	Require DCO for commits	As this is a new repository, I activated the [protobot/dco](https://github.com/apps/dco) bot to check that all commits have a sign-off. The CHAOSS Project Charter requires that all contributions are signed-off. \r\n\r\nFor users of the git command line interface, a sign-off is accomplished with the `-s` as part of the commit command: `git commit -s -m 'This is a commit message'`\r\n\r\nFor users of the GitHub interface, a sign-off is accomplished by writing `Signed-off-by: Your Name <YourName@example.org>` into the commit comment field. 337270	25434	277253	\N	\N	2019-05-30 15:15:36	Discussion on responsiveness metrics	The goal of this task is to start the discussion about the several ways we can track responsiveness metrics.\r\n\r\nFrom a broader perspective, this responsiveness metrics can be seen in several of the data sources for software development.\r\n\r\nAs an example, a code review process may have several steps such as:\r\n* the time to merge\r\n* the time waiting for a submitter action\r\n* the time waiting for a reviewer action\r\n* the time for each of the iterations in a code review process\r\n* the time to merge into master since a review is approved\r\n* the time for approval\r\n* the time to first response\r\n\r\nIn addition to this, we may find other measurable times at places such as in a mailing list, the first time to get an answer. Or in a more forum-based format such as Discourse or Stackoverflow where we can have the time to get an accepted answer.\r\n\r\nWith all of this in mind, and as a suggestion, we may start writing down the motivation of these metrics (mainly the goals we're following) and then start producing the specific questions and metrics.\r\n\r\nAs potential goals related to this, I have in mind a couple of them:\r\n* Efficiency in the software development process\r\n* Volunteers community care\r\n	\N	5	2019-08-08 15:33:09	\N	\N	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-common	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-common/issues/13	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-common/issues/13/labels{/name}	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-common/issues/13/comments	https://api.github.com/repos/chaoss/wg-common/issues/13/events	https://github.com/chaoss/wg-common/issues/13	open	MDU6SXNzdWU0NTAzNTg5MjM=	450358923	469119	GitHub API Worker	0.0.3	GitHub API	2019-10-19 16:24:37	13

337278	25434	277332	\N	\N	2018-05-10 18:14:20	New metric: Geographic Coverage	It would be interesting to track the geographic location of the committers to an open source project.
